content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll skip the stuff about it beeing 8 player coop and sooo on and start talking about the stuff that might not be mentioned as often in short reviews:The game offers multiple difficulties.. however the base difficulty is intended to be rather challenging for Players. Which is definitly a good thing since it's all about improving your own skill and after many defeats rewarding yourself with your very first win... somewhat darksouls-esque.. ----Classes:So far there's a total of 8 classes and depending on what the player wishes to accomplish every class has one or more  distinctive roles.(Tank, Healer, DmgDealer,Scout....)List of the Classes:Demolitioner,Medic, Hellfire(aka.Firebat), Marksman, Terminator, Recon, Assault, Heavy Support----Playerstats/Rewards/Achievements:There are different ranks and medals you can unlock. However, while the high ranked players get stat bonuses and unlock new skills as reward, it's still very balanced:(stats of max Rank 25 player are probably 1.3-1.8 times as high as the stats of Rank 1 player) Boosters:You unlock boosters which are very similar to perks known from games like CoD4-6 increasing stats like ms, HP, Armor, XP... You can choose 3 Boosters per Game Session.----GameContentAmount >>> Randomness >>> Replayability:Each Class has a variety of modules(which if you pick them for a game each unlock 1 or multiple passive or active skills)Weapons:There is also a variety of weapons(which not only have different dmg stats but also different purposes e.g.  light weapons that reduce enemy armor vs. Heavy weapons with high Dmg output vs. explosive weapons vs. weapons with aoe dmg but limited range of usage or high ammo consumption/cooldown) Some Weapons can use Multiple Ammotypes(HollowPoint vs Piercing)Further one can also use the environment as weapon-> throwing explosive fuel Barrels or blowing up Toxic and Radioactive Canisters or Bombs planted by Insurgents.Damage Types:There is a number of Dmg TypesHollowPoint; Piercing; Fire; Toxic; Energy; Explosive; each and every one has their pros and cons, since some Zombies and Bosses have certain resistances towards specific Dmg TypesMissions:They are randomized to a somewhat high extend they may take place in different locations and feature different enemies and objectives e.g.: Defusing Bombs, stopping a Nuclear Meltdown, Hunting/Capturing Creatures and so on.Gamemodes:Besides the Main storyline theres a Number of additional gamemodes and modifiers you can mix them just the way you want it giving you control over difficulty and Playstyle of a GameSession:-Bunkermode(You're being Supplied with resource and have to protect a beacon)-Red Storm(When You're outside of buildings your armor gets depleted and you move slower unless the storm stops for a    brief time giving you the chance to safely change location to another building)-Swarm(Creatures Have less HP but there's a whole lot more of them coming towards you)-Hardcore(Additional Random Spawns of Bosses and Special Creeps/Events)----Stuff I did not mention in this review: Random Environment Settings/MapsAll these  factors provide a huge range of possibilities ensuring very high level of replayability. The Customisation options offer a level of control to the Gameplay, ultimatly providing a high level of balance resulting in hours of fun.Ofcourse I am biased nevertheless everybody looking for a challenge or just for some coop action should give the game a try( you check out the official website for a demo version).. but watch out if you manage to survive the first hour you might already be hooked ;-)

Posted: August 27, 2016
												Great game and you can tell by the hours put in that I got my $20 worth. I am unable to recommend this game due to the community however (there are a few great people that I had the pleasure of meeting). If you enjoy being forced to join Teamspeak and listen to others calling a newer player an "idiot" because of a simple mistake then the community may not bother you. I have been in sales/customer service most of my life so I deal with far worse day to day but I draw a line when people who pay to enjoy their free time are belittled. The only reason I now leave this review, which is soley my opinion, is due to receiving a permanent forum ban w/o breaking any of the Steam rules and guidelines. To those who put in time and effort to create this game; thank you for occupying approximately 40 days of my life.**EDIT**I am updating this review to show appreciate to a member of the developing team for extending an apology based on my experience. My review doesn't change due to the prime aspect (multiplayer) of the game being a difficult obstacle to overcome due to average players, learning curve, and annoyance of hazings (I can't speak of recent experience on this but you can look at the forum discussions and see mods continuously being rude with no reprecussion of their steam violations).To highlight the game itself. This game game me a sense of accomplishment at times. You work cooperatively (and voice comminucation certainly does make things easier but not necessarily impossible) in up to 8 player PvE.  The environment can be very challenging depending on difficulty and options selected. The main group generally stays tight and loots bigger buildings early while a person or two wander to areas less traveled late game. It's easy to become overwhelmed and gameover at almost any point early on. After a good tutor or 100-200 hours this is a memory except on higher difficulties. The time investment to have a grasp on roles, map coverage, wave tendencies is another slight barrier...but we all hope a game grasps our attention for much longer. Graphics are decent but you also need a machine to accomodate with larger waves and monster variations. I can't disregard the game itself...only speak on experience. The game isn't the only part of the picture for me to have an opinion on either.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Got into it quite early in the Beta, when it was still a bit of a buggy mess. You still played it, because it was fun. The learning curve is nothing to laugh about, and it is not exactly the noobfriendliest of communities, especially some of the first players sometimes lack the nerves to deal with new players. Once you get into it though, you will have an awesome experience. Highly tactical, once you get off "Soldier"-difficulty, relies 100% on each teammate. By now the game has several different maps, playable on 4 difficulties and a handful of different modes that change up the experience like the "Red Storm" mode where you are weak when outside of buildings, but stronger inside, or swarm and fast modes that increase the pressure on your squad. All with 8 different classes, completely customizable with different weapons and abilities, that have to be utilized harmoniously to win.Protip: Get a mic. Theres a central TRS teamspeak server, that anyone in the game lobby can give you, and coordinating an 8 man team is just so much easier with voice. Learning the game and getting taught will be 10 times faster if you go on ts with one or two of your squadmates.The best way to get into it would be to grab a few freinds, put it on easy, and just jump into it. You will die. A LOT. but thats fine, and you will have fun getting to know all the different abilities and weapons before getting on with the pros who might be more interested in winning than teaching.Sadly, this game has a very small player base, so don't expect to play 8 man games 24/7. There are high times each day, where there are usually 2-4 different games going on, but expect to do some waiting in lobby for members. However, this means that you get to know people very quickly, and if you are somewhat nice and don't harass people, you will be welcomed in the community.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I played The Red Solstice a lot during the alpha test, and wrote up an alpha hands-on that explains why I like this game.  Here is the link just in case anyone might find it useful since much of it still applies to the early access test:http://www.deathbybeta.com/2014/04/09/the-red-solstice-alpha-hands-on/What was great about the game then is still great now, and things will improve over time during the early access test.  TRS is a challenging co-op game that pulls no punches.  You will die a lot, and it can be frustrating.  But, at the same time, it can extremely satisfying when your team pulls off a successful run.  Not for the faint of heart or easily frustrated, but highly recommended if you like hectic co-op isometric tactical shooters.In addition, there is a lot of tactical depth to the game that isn't apparent at first glance.  Having eight classes, each with their own skills, means that team composition can vary widely and be tailored to the strategy.  Faster marines for highly mobile teams and scouting, or slow but heavily armed marines for hunkering down.  Each class shares a global XP rank that benefits all classes, but then has its own XP rank for just that class.  This means that specializing can really pay off in the long run.In game there is a large number of items that can be found and used (mines, turrets, medical supplies, ammo, tac-nukes, and so on), and proper use of these can also greatly affect the tactics.  All in all, a very exciting nail-biting game.  The early access build is not without some glitches, and it is missing a lot of content, SO KEEP THAT IN MIND before purcahsing the game right now.  Nonetheless I am very much enjoying the game just as much as I did during the alpha.

												Been playing this for a while now but only casually.  If you're happy to be a follower and support the team it doesn't get too complicated but if you want to master any particular character it can become a much more rewarding experience albeit frustrating at times.  My main concern is there will always be players who will put unnecessary pressure/blame when things go pair shaped - ignore these bullies and just play for enjoyment.The more I play the more I enjoy the team work necessary to survive, each character has a roll and must contribute to the team.  Once you master one character and find a good setup (yet to really do as I'm not a perfectionist) just swap and start experimenting with another character as you can definitely put in plenty of hours levelling up each character and get a different experience with each.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I feel bad writing this review, because even with a thumbs up, I feel like I'll be cutting the game off at the knees. But better you know the truth, I guess.First off, the game is based on a WC3 custom map called Night of the Dead. You are space marines prancing around a Mars colony full of zombies. You select a suit (read: class), a primary weapon, a secondary weapon, 4 suit components (read: skill...not trees. Paths, maybe? 5 sequential, mostly passive abilities), up to 3 powerups (which add some bonuses at the cost of other penalties), and you go off to try and survive a ~1 hour long match. You find items and accomplish objectives which will strengthen your team, while endless waves of zombies try to murder you to death. The customization isn't that deep, but you'll find plenty to tinker with if you're the fiddy sort. I enjoy it greatly.Singleplayer exists, but it's not the focus. You control 4 marines and run around doing the same kind of stuff. It's fun. Probably not full price fun, but fun nonetheless.Multiplayer is the real heart of the game. In order to stand any chance, each player must possess basic tactical acumen and practice it for the entirety of the hour. Further, you have to possess some expertise in your class and use the right abilities at the right times, and understand the flow and structure of the game. Put simply, you are going to lose. You're going to lose a lot. It's a very hard game. Some vets will come and say "oh, no, it's not hard, just git gud". Well, fair enough, but the game has a very steep learning curve. It's simple to play, very difficult to master. That's a good thing, I think. But still, expect to lose a crap ton.There is a meta-progression, where you increase in rank (which unlocks stuff, and gives some very minor bonuses) and suit rank (gives very minor bonuses to a particular class when you play it), and medals (also small, but welcome bonuses to individual suits). It starts off fast, but becomes extraordinarily grindy to max. But that's OKAY. When I say very minor bonuses, I mean it. The game is much like Left 4 Dead, or Vermintide in that the game is almost entirely about good teamwork, and somewhat about individual skill, and very little about raw stats or xp. About 70% of winning is teamwork, 20% is individual competence, 9% is having enough xp to play the classes you need, and 1% is xp-rewarded stat bonuses. On top of all that, you can prestige (yes, lose one full 0 to max xp amount) in order to get even more tiny bonuses. That said, unless you're a total no-lifer, don't expect to max anything here.Now let's talk about the community. In order to accomplish anything, you will need to bring friends or make friends. I was able to take my little gaming collective of 3 into the game and we died a bunch, but we were able to improve considerably and also not hate or ruin the game for each other. That's pretty ideal. If you can't bring your own friends, you'll probably need to find a few veterans on the forums. The community is incredibly small, and if you just join a public game, you will get 5 minutes in, and then die, and everyone else will die, and everyone will swear a lot and blame each other. You will swear that nobody else in the world but you knows how to play the game better than a chimpanzee with a congenital learning disability. You will rage that it will take you 9650 games to reach the next rank if you keep dying on wave 2. You will go out into the darkness, and there will be a great wailing and gnashing of teeth. Sometimes, you'll sit in the lobby and there won't be enough people to form one lousy game.Yeah. You need to either bring your own community to this game, or else ingratiate yourself to the crusty old veterans who've solved this puzzle ages ago.But overall, I recommend this game as everything about it is a labor of love. They adapted Night of the Dead from Warcraft 3 to bring the game to its fullest potential, to introduce it to new people, many of whom don't even own Warcraft 3. It's certainly not for the money, given the sad state of the community. And the players work on it out of passion too. I see more and higher quality guides for Red Solstice than I see for most AA games these days. The people who make and play this game obviously care about it a lot. There is some talk about how to strengthen the community, but the fact of the matter is, in my opinion, you just can't. It's a niche game, it's a difficult game, it has virtually no marketing, and the story is the narrative version of a toupee. 99% of gamers would take one look at it and turn right around. Red Solstice is a hidden co-op gem, on the same level as AI War. It's a very rare taste. It'll never be very popular, and that's fine, because it doesn't need to be. It's just fun. I like it a lot.One last note: expect to do a lot of research. Many of the deeper mechanics are buried within documentation that exists only on the forum, or one guy's steam guide, and some haven't been written down at all.

												I love this game.If you played the Warcraft 3 Custom Map Night of the Dead ( NotD ) or the various versions of it in SC2, you will feel pleasantly reminded of them once playing this game. It is very much so inspired by them and the gameplay is similar, but also fleshed out and this game incorporates many new aspects, such as the leveling system, the various skills, and the ability to create your class before "dropping" into a mission/map.Teamplay is key in multiplayer, but you can enjoy the Solo-Mode as well and the game seems to adjust automatically to the amount of players, making it possible to play it with only a handful of friends or even just two player CO-OP.If you like cooperative missions with great atmosphere ? Get this game !10/10

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												The game itself is fantastic. Cool story (well you already know it, sort of) decent graphics, even on my old 4850 GPU, and matching music and sfx.BUT...The devs need to clean up a lot of bugs, it is only playable 3 out of 5 times due to these randomly interfering errors:(pick at least any two - list may not be complete)[ ] Game does not allow for switching to tactical mode aka "bullet time" (makes it unplayable, you need this) - edit: In certain game modes this option has to be manually activated during game setup.[ ] Bot Team members stop following the "follow" order - edit: in some game modes this requires an alternative key sequence. C'm on !?[ ] Placed explosives cannot be selected and detonated, they simply won't focus any more IF they were placed before reaching a checkpoint and after rewinding to that checkpoint. The whole checkpoint thing does not work, as you are set back in time, yes, but supplies are just as low as in the moment before you rewound. So rewinding to a checkpoint is just pointless.[ ] Health and armor bars vanish from the overview[ ] Minimap is obscured by some key binding hints that just wont go away - edit: that seems to be so on purpose. Even more annoying.[ ] Item capacity in inventory gets over exploited (i.e. "you have 15 of 10") - that one I don't mind :)[ ] There are possibly some more, I have played it only for a couple of hours.However the missions are of varying difficulty, some are absurdly difficult - even in rookie mode.This game could do much better and I would really join in on all the praise I read here, if the devs fixed it.The way the game comes now is frustrating, as the glitches really ruin the fun, especially when you have an otherwise good run and have to quit it, just because. There are no save slots.However I may not have gotten down to every aspect of it, as it is an extremely complex game.You really need to read a lot, to get into.Edit: my edits were added after I got a bit deeper into it. So this game is mainly multi player, but has a single story mode. That one I was refering to in my first version of the review.Multiplayer is way more fun. BUT I have never seen more than 10 ppl online at the same time.In multiplayer there is a wide gap as to what you can do as rookie player compared to the pros, so expect to die a lot (and spend the rest of the mission watching) when you do not have a maxed out setup. And that takes sooooome time: There are 8 classes to be played, each has a specific level of 0 to 10 while you as the player have another level of 0 to 25 (that rises with any class). Some clases only become available after you have a certain amount of XP earned with others. This concept is quite cool as personal and class-individual bonuses stack. So once you have risen to a certain personal level (you advance both level types during play), this makes switching to a new class not as frustrating as starting at square one.So, you may have guessed it. This is obviously for ppl that have time to spare and really wanna get into it. Then again I think it's not that captivating (the story is always pretty much the same), but that is up to you. The mission items and objectives are not as dull as in some other games, but, well, after some time... they are pretty much the same.The same in all games to be honest. Yeah, you may switch the map, but the story unfolds all the same.The last paragraph containes the word "same" at least four times. That pretty much summs it up.To me this looks more like a decent beta version than a real game.I'll kook into this after some time.I am not convinced.And apart from saying so, it just has nothing to do with mars. It's just for the story.Tested version was 1.175

												Release review. Well its been a year and the game has improve with more polish. It now comes with a Single player Story mode and a Single player roaming game. But the bread and butter of this game is Mulitplayer. So for this game to do well is pretty much the community doing its part teaching new players that want to play and teach them with patiences. There is always one or two fools that just won't jive with the group but its only one game. So what to come down to it is... Prepare to die and die some more . At the end of your first victory you be hook on the drug 8 play co-op game  call TRS. Btw i have about 1300hrs in.. so yea** Early Acess Review as of 12-20-2014**8 Player Co-OP. If your a fan of the War3 mod or the SC2 where teamwork is key to survive the game then look no futher. The game is fun and addictive but has a moderate learning curve. The grind for skills isn't that bad since most of the major skill a player would use in any classes could be attain in 5-6 games depending on ability to play the game. *Playing mode* There are as 2 maps playable and a 3rd one in testing. This is all for CO-OP. There is no single player at this moment but should be added but no time table for it. To me this game primary focus is the CO-OP aspect to create a growing community and hope for an editor to come out to provide user created content soon!!You can ask your questions here and I will try to answer them correctly to the best of my ability. The developers are active and particpate with the community on daily bases and patches come frequent enough with fixes and new content. The community with is still growing but are open to new people to joining everyday. You will meet people all over the world with one goal in common to kill zombies and spray lead till they stop moving. *****TLDR*****Pro-- Good game, Growing community, Responsive Developers, CO-OP fun.Con-- Growing community, Lack of Single Player for some people atm, Moderate learning curve *note*I play this game for about 700hrs so my POV is over the progress from the start of the game till now.Ask questions if you like.

content:
Posted: January 7
												I cannot recommend this game to most people. My issue with The Red Solstice is that it feels flawed and incomplete, it is plauged by questionable design decisions and poor balancing combined with a steep learning curve. All that being said the game can be quite fun when playing with a few friends of similar experience level and if you have a group of four or more to play and learn this game with you may find something enjoyable here, but for everyone else I would advise staying away. The single player campaign is serviceable but quickly gets rote, and the multiplayer component is dissapointing due to many questionable design choices and poor balancing that is made worse by the experience gap new players will face when joining a lobby with veteran players. You'll find yourself confused and more or less useless for a number of hours before being able to contribute to the team, and once you learn how to properly play the game you'll likely find the experience is not at all what you wanted in the first place. The game works against itself in a number of ways that inhibit strategy and interdependence of the classes. The demolitions class for instance will be made almost entirely useless due to the abundance of lootable explosives IF the team even decides to rely on these devices, but more importantly you can beat the game without ever placing a single explosive or launching a single rocket. Indeed most players merely circle the map with auto-fire on while the faster classes loot ammo. There is never really a need to set up static defense, and on the higher difficulties where it would potentially be viable, the cooldown on such abilities makes it impossible anyway. On top of this few teams will think about their location in relation to enemy units and often times are in the line of fire of heavy ordinance which makes it impossible to use without killing a friendly. The depth of the class system is diminished by the nature of the game.The other big problem The Red Solstice has is it's pacing. It encourages players to never stop moving. The looting, securing objectives, activating power nodes, etc all happen while on the run. Setting up a static defense is simply not supported, there is no way to lockdown doors, and even items like barricades are useless... not as in poorly implimented, as in the developers never bothered to apply collision detection to them so enemies walk right through these barricades. All slower, and defense oriented classes fail to play as one would expect as a result of this, and indeed the game becomes about patroling the map rather than each class utilizing it's niche focus to support the team. The game really only feels like it has 3 classes, the Medic, and then the rest being a DPS varient, with one acting as a fast looter. This game would be far better if it allowed for setting up actual fortifcations to secure areas and encouraged players to balance offense and defense tactics by establishing a zone of control and having mobile members fetch and secure objectives and luring hordes and large enemies into the heavy fire of your static defense. It would be far better if large enemies required explossive damage to make them vulnerable to small arms fire, it would be far better if it encouraged thinking and planning over running and gunning, especially because the game does not control like a run and gun game. It controls like an RTS, but other than presenting the facade of a strategy game, there is litle strategy to be found. I would have liked to have seen the game rely less on bullet sponge enemies and more on forcing players to manage proper firing arcs or face the deadly consequences. Instead the marine behaves in typical rts faction and spins and shoots incoming enemies automatically. The game does provide a manual aim, but it is poorly communicated to the player and the ui for it is terrible. There is no tactical advance in this game, there is no managing firing arcs, there is no establishing a base of operations, there is no flexibility. Like an rts, you group up and blob the enemy and that is a damn shame.This sort of gameplay was acceptable when it was a modifcation for a 2003 strategy game, it is not acceptable as a stand alone title, and rather than evolve the concept they ripped it almost unchanged from the mod which inspired it. I am hopeful that with the next game in this franchise they are able to get things right, but from the looks of it so far it appears to be a less interesting alien swarm. I would advise the developers to look at titles like full spectrum warrior which required establishing firing arcs and moving the squad tactically. Translated to the rts perspective something like that could work well and better define the pace and balance of gameplay.As a stand alone genre this type of game is still new, and with that comes some hiccups. I applaud these developers for trying to establish this genre, unfortunately the title is too bogged down by the mods that inspired it.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												EDIT: TL; DR: You like true 8 player co-op? Survival? A challenge that can go to really high difficulties? Leadership and class responsability? This game is for you. Long version: This is by far the most addicting game I've ever played, due to great community, great challenge and great gameplay. I've always liked survival games and good communities. This game has both. It has people willing to teach, people willing to laugh, people willing to play as a team, and now it has lots of new people willing to learn.Each of the unique 8 classes has a role that will make surviving the hell on mars easier. And each with its own unique style of play, strenght an weaknesses.The game has big replayability, randomized missions, locations, monster spawns, bosses, everything to make every single dollar spent on it worth it. Even 1000h+ veterans still get surprised by what the game can show. And constant updates and support from the devs keep the game balanced and fresh.Seriously what are you waiting to buy this game?My review on Early access:This Game is wonderful, I've been part of the community Since Late Notd 2 And then Notd: Spec Ops. The makers of this game worked their asses off during lots of years and they deserved this final result. A true co-op survival game with good tactics and randomization. Threats that will require skill and cooperation of your teammates so you can survive. It's also possible to play alone if you're feeling pro, and the game allows you to have some bonus as you play, it's really rewarding to see your characters getting new modules and getting better stats. It's also awesome to kill big bosses or help your team to do it, and the best part is to evac with your team knowing you did your job properly, and trust me it wont be by evacing before you get to see some nasty awesome monsters.Its on early access and the game depends on people playing but really, if you're active you'll always find games and help people find games aswell. The more people that have the game, the more activity it will have, so get it! Be part of this growing community!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I found this game by searching for the multi-player co-op tags on steam.  If you're looking for that kind of experience, and like challenging games, then this game is for you.  They are reportedly working on a single player mode, but cooperative-multiplayer is where the heart of this game is.The game IS challenging.  If you are playing at the correct difficulty for your team, you will lose more often then you will win.  Even though it's early access, the game is very playable.  They've had some buggy patches but they tend to fix them pretty quick.  The devs are on a fast-release cycle and they listen to the community as to what is and isn't working, what's fun and isn't fun, and they participate in the forums.  Now that the game is more stable, the dev's have been focusing on adding more content (maps, bosses, missions, skills, etc) which is keeping the game fresh and challenging.If you can get this game on sale, or money isn't a big deal,  I'd definitely recommend the early access version.  If you are on a tight budget, you may want to wait for release.  I have ~500hours on record so far for a $20 game.  So I'm very happy with the value I'm getting.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												The red clouds part, the dropship lands at an unknown location; and 8 marines set down on the Tharsis colony. I've been one of those marines a few hundred times, and none of those drops went as planned.Your team will spend the next hour gathering items and supplies, weathering a constant flow of monsters as they roam the colony. This process begins slow, building to a crescendo as the game progresses. During the last third of the round, the danger's so intense: it requires the entire team working together to survive. This formula produces a unique and often panicked rush back to the dropship as the team tries to evacuate.There are two kinds of marines: the ones that make it back to the dropship, and the ones left behind. If you're looking for a game with deep mechanics, replayability, and a challenge, look no further.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												An awesome game made by an awesome studio as ever (based on v1.000).(下面有中文)As a member of special corps elite, your squad has been assigned to an investigation on Mars - which the colony lost contact not long after a storm dubbed "The Red Solstice".You will have to manage to survive the harsh environments and fulfill various tasks during the storm by squad-based unified action. It would be better and necessary planning your course of action ahead, trusting your teammates, coordinating with them, and sharing supplies you find along the road.Sounds a bit familiar? Yes! If you love NotD(SO/Aftermath) on WC3 or Undead Assault 3 on SC2, then this is definitely the game for you (finally), and with tons of enhancements you will find in game, love the well-made soundtracks for example.Well, if you haven't heard or (unfortunately) hate those games due to the moderate learning curve before, then you should better not miss TRS this time. There is a brand new Single Player mode for everyone to enjoy, meanwhile, you will be familiar with the gameplay, which is challenging and worth playing.For multiplayer games, it's the meaning of this game, charming and fascinating, especially cooperating with some experienced players (eg. Diode, eL gRingo, Yegor, quzexe12... too many superb players, have no luck yet to play with you all sorry).Also you can just start a Survival game which is some sort of multiplayer but just you landing with 3 bots under your command, which is a highly efficient way to master the map you’re playing with at this moment.Anyway, it's a style of easy to learn, challenging to master co-op game, yet eventually skilled players will have the feeling of satisfaction from the heart. It's something about trust, co-ops and fighting for survival.So marines, cheer up! Welcome aboard and good luck out there, you'll need it :)In a word, an addictive game and no doubt worth having. 9.5/10 (personally)Thanks to everybody in the studio and devs online as Syrus and others too, we finally have this baby given birth today because of your hard work.Thanks to everyone in the community that firmly supported this baby in the past days, we all have made our common dreams come true.In fact, in this respect, I'm sure senior member Commander Wrecker is doing better ;)http://steamcommunity.com/app/265590/discussions/0/530646715637543149/Salute,cheers! ;)----------------------------------------这款确是极好的，Ironward工作室的又一款高逼格作品。地点：火星。在一次席卷大洲的腥红风暴后不久，整个火星殖民地的通讯陷入了沉寂。作为特种陆战队中的一员精英，你的小队被指派前往调查。然而在着陆后不久你们便发现，将要对抗的（又）是潮水般不知疲倦的亡者大军。根据以往的经验，你们尝试计划行进路线，并默契地交叉掩护，时而全开火力，时而奔命街头， 分享利用着有限的物资补给。似乎你们在这场疯狂中生存了下来……听着很耳熟？没错！如果你钟爱魔兽3的亡者之夜（特别行动/余波）系列，或者星际2的不死突袭3，那无疑这就是你的菜。这款续作在职业可塑性、游戏可玩体验、易操作度、团队沟通便利度，以及该系列故作（死）高（不）大（悔）上（改）的新兵非友善向方面等等等等，都有着诚意十足的良心改进。如果你还未听说过这个系列或者很不幸的一直操作苦手，那你不应该错过这款续作，"The Red Solstice"。游戏里加入了全新的单人剧情模式，在享受乐趣的同时，你已经成为了半个老鸟。据（无责任）小道消息，仅单人剧情便具有很高的挑战性和可玩性。好了大兵，准备好了吗？多人大厅随时等待你的加入，来这里我们一起战个痛快。友情提示：小心上瘾。个人给9.5/10分

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												     There is alot to like about this game, but I'm not sure the bad outweigh the good.  Some of the biggest problems are the controls, game difficulty, and the beta state of the game.     The controls are an absolute pain.  You will constantly default to the team leader when you change control modes.  Autofire will turn on when you select another team member.  Sometimes your team will follow you, sometimes the game will toggle off autofollow.  Sometimes you will put out a squad in tactical mode, then the team will assemble on the leader immediatly on leaving the mode.  All these things feel intentional, however and only make the game feel clunky by design.  Other games might get away with it but as frantic as the later levels can get, you will see your team wipe due to this.       I laughed when I saw a note at the start of one level, saying the waves of enemies are NOT endless.  They did feel endless at many points, and that indicates the difficulty.  Too much is not explained, or poorly explained in the game.  Some levels are purely trial and error.  Save points are fairly far between.  At first the game comes across as a frantic, tactical game.  After a few levels it feels like a forced rush to finsh quickly.  Some levels you can slow down and think it out, others you have a set path to victory that is explained in no way, except dont die.     So much is odd about this game.  The skill discriptions that say "Discription Not Found".  The story explained in a text block in the options.  No idea how to gain experience.  I found a few guides that said you gained experience from looting lockers (???).  Alot of this feels like new ideas, and if it was explained in some way I'd give the devs the benefit of the doubt, but it feels lazy and half finished.  Also, I will mention the hoops you need to jump through to get it to run is staggering.  I spent a few days trying to get it to run, just to give up in frustration.  6 months later I tried on a new PC, and it started up without a hitch.       The game has some really cool moments and is addictive to a point.  That point is when you realize its nearly broken in difficulty at certain points.  I'm not really sure the game is worth the purchase price, whatever it is, considering its a dice roll to get it to run.  If you enjoy zombie games, and tactical shooters, it might be worth a look.

number of helpful: 17 of 24 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												The Red Solstice is an awesome RTS set on a futuristic Mars colony. You are the leader of a marine squadron sent to investigate the derelict Tharsis colony. As the game progresses, you will be taught new things about the game mechanics and be forced to use everything you learned about the old ones. You will die though. A lot. One second I was happily following mission objectives and the next 2 of my squad members were down and I was being swarmed by enemies. The game also features Tactical Mode, which allows you to slow down the action and make tactical decisions to take down enemies. Squad Management is deep but surprisngly easy to use, allowing you to customize nearly every aspect of each marine such as bullet type, weapons, suits, abilities, you name it. The music is amazing and does a spectacular job of immersing you in the action. Enemies are plentiful and exploits are few, so be prepared for a fun, exciting, and challenging experience.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												For anyone who missed something anywhere near the lines of Alien Swarm, this is something that at least hits the lines of "Similar." Meaning that this is a highly team based overhead style game where classes actually seem to matter with a sickening amount of fine tuning options available to each of the eight classes. Up to eight players are allowed in a game, though there are specific limitations on how many instances of each class allowed typically either 4, (Assault) 2, (Heavy Support, Medics, etc) or only 1 (Hellfires, Terminators, Etc.) Though as there isn't a infinite ammunition system and a toss mag reload (Meaning anything left in the magazine when reloaded is "Tossed" or simply lost.) ammunition can quickly become sparse.The voice acting in the single player game is terrible and it feels, clunky especially in the beggining levels, so I spent most of my time on multiplayer scenarios.Upon which comes my biggest lament with the game. Characters are allowed two weapons, a primary weapon and a secondary. Of the secondary weapons available there is a handgun or pistol. For whatever reason this uses primary weapon ammunition regardless of if it happens to be napalm, full metal jacket, or hollowpoint. Which renders it's overall effectiveness somewhat questionable compared to a grenade launcher, Rocket launcher, or even shotgun which use their own ammunition pool and have vast room clearing capacities compared to a pistol. Granted, a Hellfire can replenish their GAR (Gauss Assault Rifle) from a fuel barrel in this so maybe the point is moot... If one enjoyes wave/endless monsters trying to claw their jibblies while trying to complete objectives in a story-esque fashion and all the chaos involved with it, especially with up to eight friends... then your likely going to sink much more time into this than you had origionally planned. The mechanics of the game are good (With the occasional wall where explosives may pass through) the only failing point so far is to make a truly engaging story singleplayer. Having a bad voice acter (Think like a B movie commando that can no where near sell it or a solid snake impersonator) whom the player is FORCED to listen to quickly ruins any immersion and saps the will to continue. My reccomendation is to play it how it seems to be meant to. As multiplayer. Grab your guns, and your comrades, and never stop firing, otherwise your going to be picking claws out of your backside.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Don't get discouraged by reviews of people who get frustrated by dying early. This is a game that doesn't hold your hand, has a complex system and has quite a learning curve. it is advised for new squads to do easy difficulty first to familiarize. It shines on multiplayer but you have to do your due diligence (i.e. Go through single player, familiarize with items etc.) This game is not about grinding through the ranks. A team of 8 who knows the game  can create new accounts and beat the game while they're all at rank 1. It's about teamwork, respecting the enemies (why most new players die is they don't respect the swarm), achieving goals as a team, and playing your role (as medic, tank, dps/carry, utility, scout, forward observer etc.).  If you are a fan of the old top down squad games like Night of the Dead, Undead Assault and its ilk, this game is for you. If you want a challenging/complex game that requires teamwork and has hero-based system, you'll like this game.CONS:- Single player can only give you 10 to 20 hours of fun. Most of the fun is in multiplayer.- Only a few maps to go through. I believe the devs can create a random map generator. There is a tactical advantage though of knowing the map.- high difficulty. This is a team game. If the healer doesn't know what to do, or the tank, then the squad will most likely fall. There is a need for a good leader at higher difficulties.- medium to steep learning curve, depending on how good you want to be.- if you die early, you will be automatically revived if you are new to the game. However, after a few ranks, there will no longer be an automatic revive. A medic or a mission can revive you, but you will have to wait.PROS- Team game. I've played with Europeans, Chinese, Canadians and Americans. A good world we are in. At higher difficulties, you need to talk, so teamspeak would be necessary. There's a different sense of achievement when you defeat a game as a team.- Hero-based system. You control one character, customize it and change its load out. There are 8 classes that each have a role to play. Mastery of a class is a journey and there are different ways to build a single class.- Squadron tactics. You have an enemy sniper shooting at 124m away while a swarm is constantly flowing to your team, what do you do? 3 big fatties chasing you? Fast dogs gnawing at one of your team? Some military squad tactics apply, like leapfrog movements, defensive positions, buddy system etc. The squad leaer has a large impact and responsibility.- Random missions and enemies. Every game is different depending on the mission, the boss spawn etc.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Ever since playing the indoor missions of the original Starcraft campaign I hoped for a standalone game focussing on this setting. And here it is.TRS combines the looks and feel of Starcraft, blends in some DOTA-like micro control but has the players act cooperatively against waves of zombies and alien monsters a bit like Left For Dead.However, this blend of threats and mission makes you realize quickly that you need to know your way around before succeeding. By the setting and enemy waves alone, the game is substantially more difficult to master than many of today's games. The difficulty adds to the addictive character of the game - lots of replayability.The developers continuously keep on improving the game and gameplay. Additionally, they are always open for your suggestions and eager to receive your crash reports. There is a close connection between game community and  developers.RTS is multiplayer focussed and purely cooperative so be on the lookout for a decent team / squad. At the moment the RTS community is rather small so at times it might be frustrating not to find enough players for your match. This is the only drawback I see and it might become resolved soon once there is a bigger community.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me tell you something straightaway: you're going to die, no two ways about it; either it'll be some jackaloon in your squad with an itchy trigger finger and a grenade launcher, or it'll be a bio-engineered thunderbeast from the seventieth dimension of Hentai Mountain using its tentacles on you in ways it's best not to describe in polite company. Your death is more or less inevitable.The question is: How are you going to face that death?Crying like a coward and blaming your teammates for leaving you stranded in a distant corner because you wanted that shiny little +5% to weapon damage, the legion of GWAR fans on your tail be damned?Laughing at the ludicrous nature of the spiky-humpbeast which is making your backside its domain?Screaming bloody murder as you drop a SHIVA TacNuke device on your now overrun position?Staring in mute amazement, your head ripped clean off and sailing through the air, as that jackass whose been surviving alone the entire game activates the Evac and then gets there first, spawning wave after wave of the gigantic 'hatchlings' which have just de-crowned you?Sobbing deeply and sadly as your small, insignificant life snuffed out before it even began, kicked at random by lobby host after lobby host for no reason other than the fact that they like skulls and your name had one next to it? You will die, it's as simple and indifferent as that. But how you face that death? That choice is yours. 1/10 Team AI sucks.11/10 Rock and Roll Music when bad things are happening.5/10 "Easy" is just a codeword for 'slightly (1%) less tentacles'10/10 Getting into an Evac before the entire team and being the only one to survive, Would do again.0/10 Lack of mustaches on Marines.

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												The Red Solstice is pretty much the Aliens: Colonial Marines simulation I have always wanted. My search started way back when Alien Swarm was still a thing, but every game I tried lacked something, you know? Well, I for one am glad to have found this game! I've clocked in over 200 hours of game play and I don't think I have play a game for that many hours besides WOW. Defiantly spend your money on this title ladies and gents. I haven't seen a game do this genre justice in a very long timeI came for alien shooter genre, but I stayed for in depth game play mechanics. This game has got it all for sure. Inventory management, intense team work, tactical over shooting, mutant monsters, an over-run colony, nukes, drop ships, flame throwers, knives, sharp sticks...you get the picture. I could go own and list all the features, but that would be better served by playing The Red Solstice (TRS).So here are a few important things to know about TRS. TRS is freaking HARD! It doesn't do a whole lot of hand holding and rarely pulls it punches. If you make a stupid play or think this game is a solo Rambo action game, the monsters will feast on your stupid corpse, and more importantly, they'll eat your friends while they are still alive. How do I not be stupid you ask? Well learning how to play the game better that's how. And how you do that is by dying...A LOT. Get use to the game over screen because you will see it ever day you play. Don't get discouraged though, it's part of the learning experience. Even death you still serve, um, I mean you gain XP for rank and speicalist XP for your class that your playing. The more waves and missions you complete the more XP you gain. And of course you'll get better at the game  and you'll no longer do silly things like trying to figure out how to use a satchel charge in the middle of a huge wave of monster while your whole team is in the blast radius (yes I was that dumb once). Enough of my rambling. I'll see in the elevator to hell, going down!

content:
Posted: February 26
												The Red Solstice starts as a pretty typical "lone squad must defeat hordes of horrific creatures overrunning the colony" plot, but manages to throw in several twists both in the game and in the plot to make things interesting. While the game can be played as a regular RTS, where you guide the squad and let them shoot anything in sight, by mission 4 or 5 you get curveballs, such as enemies that doesn't appear on sensors (so auto-aim doesn't work) but manual aimming does. Then you get into HUGE enemies (7500 hp!) that basically forces you to utilize each soldier's specialty power, such as gunship strafing, artillery beacon, grenade launcher, HE shells, so you can survive the fight. Gunship strafings can take out a large group of enemies, while artillery beacon can be placed then enemy lead over it so the barrage clean them out. Explosives can be placed, mines can be set, and so on. On the other hand, your soldiers can be seriously hit including poison, broken bones, septic wound, and more. Each soldier can only carry 6 items (some of which can have QTY > 1) so item management can be important as no one can carry everything. In RTS mode, movement controls are limited, but once you enter tactical mode, you can move soldiers about and give more individualized orders. Time also slows down tremendously, giving you time to give precise orders, like go here and kill that (and stay there).  My main gripe with the game is difficulty in accessing all four members of the team, as usually you can only access the team leader. Only in tactical mode can you access all four members. This makes for a very awkward interface when you're the kind of guy that goes after every locker, where you could find inventory from bandages to explosvies.  These are the "crates" in this universe. But the increased reaction time makes entire mess actually doable. All in all, the tactical mode needs a bit polishing, otherwise it's one fun game.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Red Solstice is the type of game I hate to love. The concept is cool, the gameplay feels solid, and its co-op to boot. Except, the atmosphere is different. Back when the game first released and everyone was lvl 1, there were no hard set strategies or metas, just groups of eight strangers yoloing through an unforgiving environment with not a care in the world. When I came back to the game after a yearish hiatus, everyone expected me to min-max one specific character class, or take a hike. Classes like the recon were shunned like the plague, because their dps was less than stellar. I understand the desire to succeed (and I don't fault others for it), but playing one class with one set build for 40+ hours the same exact way is not how I have fun. To each their own, I guess. Unless 7 other people with the exact same schedule want to hang out with a meta noob, I don't plan on returning to this game any time soon.TL;DR Friends are great, metas are not.Edit: Thank you Ironward, Thank you. After another break from this game, I came back to find that the mp bots are actual characters that can be customized and leveled, just like a regular player character. Combined with the tactical mode's slow motion, I can play a mp match solo. Wish I didn't have to play mp matches solo in the first place, but this is the next best thing. I will gladly reccomend this game now.

content:
Posted: February 11
Product received for free
												I played this game when it first came out and I immediately fell in love with it. It's a slick tactical shooter. With hordes of alien zombies trying to kill you. Meanwhile your team of husky voiced men attempt to complete your objectives.Again it's a great game. I stopped playing it for some time and decided to get back into it and immediately fell back in love.Great set of classes Assault-great all rounder very good beginner class. he's  great with light weapons and rifles and he even smokes a cigar. Do you want to live forever?Hellfire-your typical tank takes the beating while keeping your men safe he also has a giant flamethrower pyromaniacs special delightMedic-takes the role of making sure your teamates don't die and in this game that happens A LOT. It's only a flesh woundDemolition- if you like to watch things go boom and enjoy massive exsplosions this is your guy. Larger skill cap but if you can master it the doorway for badassness is endless. Other warning high team kill ratio.Recon- very slick scouting class this guy generally works very well with a marksmen but also has the ability to call in support whether it be drone strikes or artillery barrages. Heavy support- big hulking man carries around giant minigun waylaying death in the sound of thousands of rounds being expended. This guy is a general buffer to your teamates and also can assist in slowing enemy advances in the use of suppressive fireMarksman-  you ever run into a situation where a giant monster is about to kill you and all the sudden it dies in one hit? Well this guy is a special at it. He excels at far range sniping and is excellent at cover fire. He's a little slower then his other comrades but dam he makes up for it with stopping powerTerminator- here's your wild card he carries a giant prototype energy based weapon called the vindicator. He can teleport and overload his weapon to annihlate everything including your teamates. The maps range from massive to slightly large and offer a good variety for strategyThey also have a good range of difficulties from recruit to aetriden  If you decide to purchase this game I will warn you the community is smaller than it used to be and if you purchase this game learn the mechanics and controls before jumping into a hard mode group because you will be left behind not in a mean nasty way but generally one big rule of thumb is stay with the pack.And all the reviews stating it has an elitist community I will say it does and it doesn't the thing people have to understand is this game is so reliant on all eight players working together if one guy makes an error it effects the entire team *on high end difficulties* on casual difficulties  The game is far more forgiving but is still no pushoverAsk for help and you will receive and look up some guidesThey even made a discord channelThat also being said if you liked NOTD for Warcraft/Starcraft download the $/,!ing gameThis game will always have a special place and you should give it a try. A special shoutout to the developers who created this gem thank you :)DO YOU WANT TO LIVE FOREVER MARINES!!!?!?!

												squadbased, tactical, coop-fun at ot`s best. you get an extensive singelplayermode, featured with an allright story (the voice-work is dodgy), but an excellent athmosphere (reminds me more of Warhammer than Star Craft -> which is a good thing), great sound-design and even more imprtant fantastic squadcontrol. you always fell in charge of your little marine-troop and the immersion is great.where the game realy shines is the multiplayermode, progression is engaging, running around with a full squad of marines always fearing to be overrun, while completing a pletora of different side and main targets is amazing. working together is way more important than you realize at first glanze. sharing items, giving each other cover-fire and support is what makes or brakes most maches. when you first start TRS up you might just see the somewhat dated grafics, or get overwhelmed by the scenario and feel somehwat at a loss in the mp-mode, but when you stick around to understand what`s going on you will have a blast. the heavy emphasis on cooperation is amazing and where many FPS games fail in this scenario TRS shines.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has the chance to be a premier "tactical co-op" experience. Playing as a squad of marines desperately trying to push back the stem of undead/mutants that are threatening man kind on mars, players will have to work together or perish alone. That said, the game is extremely hard, with many retries required to win a game. A single mistake or bad decision can be the difference between success and a squad wipe.In the current state, the game is quite buggy, crashes often (once every couple of games), desync causes many issues. The playerbase is plagued with elitist people (including myself, I must admit), and new players can easily find themselves lost in the steep learning curve and bashed by the more experienced. But if people are willing to stick with it, they may end up enjoying it.My best advice, do not be afraid of asking questions, people would rather help you than scorn you if you atleast ask before doing something. Newbies are treated as something to be cared about, even if they tend to do some stupid stuff.The developers are friendly, they respond to questions and bug reports, and interact with the playerbase. In time, the game should hopefully be bug free and play like a dream, we can hope at least.For early access, this is definitely a game with promise, and even in its current state, an excellent game in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												I wanted to put a couple hours into the game before I wrote a good review so here it goes. TRS is a different kind of game, that goes unsaid, if you are not into working with a team via a Chat client (Teamspeak, mumble, etc) you may see some real let downs come gameplay time. Like any other stragety game knowing what the game plan is for your team is important and without a solid communication system you will see teams in public lobbies fall before wave 10. Good news is that there is a teamspeak server dedicated to TRS (ts.game-com.de) and as a new player to the game I can say my experience went from crappy, to excellent the moment I signed on there and began playing with people. Not only do you learn a lot from more experienced players (Veterans) but you get to learn a lot of things you wouldn't find out by playing in random lobbies with random people. "But Dagnome, there is a in game chat"True, but like most games with built in VOIP it isn't very good or used at all. To sum up, if you are looking for a great team game to play with your friends then TRS will hit that sweet tooth, it can be frustrating because on teammate can screw up the whole game, but it can also be very rewarding like the time me (Medic) and an assault survived together after our team was slaughtered and evaced to safety (http://www.twitch.tv/dagnom/v/7696891).

 GAME PLAY The Red Solstice is a game of three modes, and while the core mechanics are the same, placing the title square in the real-time tactics genre with shooter elements, the way the player approaches each of the three is pretty different.Gamers take on the role of one of the marines who are sent to investigate the events surrounding the massive storm and the damage it has caused, and they will have to carefully use their weapons, movement, placement, special abilities, and other items found in the level to stay alive either to reach their goals or to get extracted.The single player created by developer Ironward is made up of ten missions and asks gamers to carefully control main character Tyler Hunt but also his squad mates, moving around the locations and achieving objectives.The Red Solstice offers a different challenge for each new level, and because the squad companions evolve from one to the next, it's important to develop them carefully and make sure that the entire group is prepared for the task ahead.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												So where do i start?I discovered The Red S0lstice about 2,5 years ago,asked if i could help out testing and BAm i was in.Man this game was so hard but it feelt so rewarding once you do manage to win :DThe Game did come a long path countles of changes hundreds of patches some of them good ,some of them bad but non the less the game evolved into something better.The game itself is not easy at the beginning everything is new, you get lost quiet often and wellyou die from time to time" Snatcher anyone?".But once you figure out how stuff works (there are plenty of guides from the community) the game gets easyer.You will have plenty of gamemodes and difficults to chose from also there are around 6 maps by now thats plenty of stuff to mess around with.Just keep going you wont regret it.I had an awesome time with the community and also the devs of this game and that seems kinda rare today in other games sadly.If you are looking for an hardcore game that req. hard teamwork and ambition in order to win and have no problem with failing a few times than this game is totaly the right one to pick.The singleplayer is in aswell you will have up to 10 missions that take you through the story and explain certain game mechanics overall for a 20$ price tag this game is awesome.Stay Frosty :)

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is epic, and only in early access.Ignore the really bad voice acting at the start, and jump in. At first you'll be thinking what the hecks going on, not enough ammo, getting swarmed by the creeps and dying fast, but stick with it for a couple of rounds multiplayer, and buddy up to a vet and a whole world will open up to you. It has good progression after the initial steep learning start, and enough different builds of skills, classes and gear to keep you going.This game is true co-op, you go it alone you die, you need your team mates, and they need you. As with all multiplayer games there are a group of jerks out there who aren't worth playing with, but just avoid them and find a good squad to run with.Mechanics are a sci-fi diablo esq, but with much more options in build and pick-upable equipment, including changing fire modes on rifle (single, burst, full auto)

Nice little strategy gameThe game offers a small team based strategy experience with zombies/monsters to kill and experience, unlockables and leveling system, so it should keep you playing for hours just to unlock things that you want to get. I first heard about the game on its full release but it seems to have been around longer so i wich i would had found it sooner since i really love the gameplay.Good: Good Combat/Strategy elements Wide variety of loadouts/Setups Challenging but not too difficult Keeps you playing for hours Muliplayer/CoOpBad: Repeative (After around 10 hours the game seems kind of too similar with the missions to do in Survival/Multiplayer, however there is few different maps to play on that adds to the variety a little)I really cant say much bad about the game since its really solid and good as for a simple strategy shooter game. I did read that peoples said they got the idea for this game from "Starcraft" custom maps wich kind of makes sence, but i still think there is enough content here to make you want to get it even if you own starcraft or love RTS or Moba type of games.For anyone that is interested i higly recommend looking into the game.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I decided to write a review on this game considering how many hours I've put into it and that It's finally out of Early Access. Personally, I think that this game is very fun and a good way to kill some time. I've never played a game with overhead and click-to-move game mechanics before; I don't prefer them. I make an exception for this game, however. The Singleplayer mode has an interesting plot and fun missions that make you think on your feet and keep you entertained while doing it. The Multiplayer always has something to do and can always be a challenge. No matter how good you get at The Red Solstice, you can never win by yourself. Using varying combat suits, skills, power ups, weapons, basically your own unique builds, you're going to have to work with your team to complete objectives and take down the big threats. I've owned this game since it first came to Steam and it certainly wasn't a purchase I regret. Get in, learn the ropes, and get ready for a slaughter. Just make sure you don't blow up your team...

content:
Posted: April 13
												First of all, i was bought on a trailer of Chronicles - it was fun, it was dynamic, it was pretty nice looking - and decided to buy Red Solstice.After almost 24 hours of playing:I don't like the game in this state at all. It had a great potential but it's all lost. - It's ridiculously slow while the tactical component is very weak.- It's repetitive in a bad way.- It lacks in-gameplay char developement almost completely (upgrades are so small variative in their effectiveness that i can't stand to critisize)- It's hardscripted in control points of events, and hardscripted in the way it's played- i played some campaign but i can't see major differences with survival which shows the face of the game- I wouldn't comment on some stupid UI solutions like lack of proper status notifications, incomprehencible status appliance from mobs, spacebar unit control, etc etc etc. Tons of ambiguous UI/UX solution.All the play scenarios is the same - you run slowly through the map entering buildings that almost all the time big and has one enterance. And then you go round the corner. For one f#$% minute. Because all characters has movement speed of an injured snail. And with that speed you ran through the whole map for five-six stupid locations, settled in the different ends of the map because devs wanted to annoy you. While being bothered with weak mobs. And after  30 minutes of clueless running(have i mentioned that quests give you nothing? and in the half game you maxed out your level?) they show the big mobs that spawns randomly and overwhelms you. While you can't effectively nether destroy the spawn points nor have any strategic solutiotions that doesnt involve building baricades from small crates you've found. And you have a EVAC module in your inventory that says "emergency EVAC" but you couldnt activate it and it's not explained why - certainly who the %^&$ needs the EVAC protocol description when it's only way to win the game. Nice work.So summarize above said there're a LOT of things to do for devs because now it plays like very badly optimized alpha version of the game.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												That's what I wanted!I remember myself playing a Warcraft III map called "Dawn of the Dead", that was long ago. Years passed by, but there was no such game released (at least, I never seen anything that would feel the same). And, finally, they brought The Red Solstice!While it's still Early Access, it already feels exactly like it should. You're out in an urban area, which is full of zombies and other creatures that thirst for your blood. You only have your squad and your skills, and you have to learn the ropes all along. Ammo's running out, people get poisoned and wounded, and enemies become stronger wave after wave. Perfect!..It doesn't really matter how many times your squad gets terminated in the game. What actually matters is your experience behind that. Failure is the foundation of success. Soon you learn to use barricades to block enemy routes. You get to count your shots carefully, and to help out your fellow teammates who are out of mags. Wave after wave, you learn more tactics and, ultimately, achieve the goal.Really looking forward to play it, big thanks to devs! Recommended for all those who like tactical and hardcore games.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a fun game with a lot going for it. Its still in EA and has bugs and optimumisation issues etc but the overall platform is stable enough for several hour sessions with no real game breakers.Gameplay is similar to DoW2 Last Stand and other games of this ilk. Players control their own characters and pick the abilities for themselves but are reliant upon the whole team (upto 8player co-op comp stomp)  trying to achieve a series of objectives while surving progessively stronger waves of enemy.There are several game option variants currently playable with more under development including the single player which hasn't yet been implemented.Controls require some familiarity but are acceptable, chat is text based at the moment but co-ordination is improved by waypoints, markers and map pings available to the 2 leaders chosen before the match. A basic objective compass is in effect throughout for everyone.When you die in match you remain a spectator with full access to the map and text to continue participating and there a re several methods of getting back into the match but nothing so simple as a "quick" pick me up by a team mate.The game won't hold your hand and is definietly challanging enough to retain interest.Summary: "Just one more match" type of fun.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This game remainds me of a Warcraft III Frozen Throne custom scenario called SWAT Aftermath. It is also similar to modern titles like Xcom. It is not turn based, but it keeps to the small team with a variety of classes, equipment, and skills. Skills are unique to the classes, and are powered up individually. That's everything I felt this game does well. If you are interested in this title, I would say wait for it to go on sale for 75% off.A few points that really made this a foul game to me:Exploration of the maps takes hours of gameplay in the single player campaign.During exploration you are constantly swarmed by enemies; there are no waves, just a steady and annoying flow.The sprint hardly increases your move speed (enemies will still catch you), and has a long cooldown.All of this makes me want to skip exploring, but almost all of the equipment and skills are discovered by exploring.Unit statistics, like evade and AR res (armor resist), are not explained, but critical to gameplay.It works, but has a few serious bugs (like enemies shooting at you through walls and hitting).

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Red Solstice is a much needed addition to any tactician or squad-based lover's game library. In it, you and up to 7 other Marines battle your way through a rather relentless horde of aliens, moving around a large map to try and complete various objectives before ultimately being overrun and forced to evacuate, or making a courageous last stand. Though there are a couple performance issues (namely clicks and keypresses not always registering when there is a full roster of players) the game is the only I've seen lately that delivers such an in-depth and tactical approach to multiplayer class-based combat. Every class is vastlly different from the others, but no single role is mandatory to a successful squad. Within certain parameters (Elysium Corp won't let you take 8 medics) the squad design is very adaptable, as is each class based on your playstyle.Tactically, the game pretty rapidly snuffs out heroes who stay away from the cluster too long, but is not unrewarding to a team that can cowardinate an effective division of tasks. Leaders of the squad can issue orders, and set waypoints for the team to follow. Rather than just relying on good communication, your team can physically see where you want them to move to. I have yet to see a game that is so rewarding to good communication and planning. It is brutally hard, and the developer holds no punches, but if you can gather a strong group of quick thinkers and loyal marines, you might just save Mars Colony.The impecable sounds, the unrivaled gameplay, and the immense tactical immersion earn this game a 10 out of 10 from ReaperEDIT: Out of Early Access for a while. Still love the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												First of all, this is not the usual twin-stick top-down shooter you might think it is!The Red Solstice has (especially in multiplayer) way more depth than you can imagine from a first look at the store page.The game lore pretty much feels like a threesome between Warhammer 40k, Starcraft and Starship troopers. A comfortable couch zone for the typical sci-fi nerd like me with no big suprises.It has a solid singleplayer experience where you can get a grasp of the core game mechanics, the different classes, weapons, perks and the inventory managment. Also only in the singleplayer part you can activate a tactical "bullet time" where you can control all of your 3 squad members in detail. The game is intended to be pretty hard and unforgiving, so even on the lowest diffuculty you can expect a hard time even as a seasoned gamer.Where it shines most in my opinion is the multiplayer part though. The mainly played mission mode ties story wise in the singleplayer campaign with different outcomes and procedual generated objectives and different bossfights. While playing you are under constant pressure from the enemy and you have to be on the move the whole time while looting and managing different important rescources like ammo, medkits and explosives for roughly 45 minutes if u dont die before that. That experience (especially while playing with a good group of 8 ppl) is a BLAST.There are also plenty of other modes to mix up your experience once a while like a defense mode or KotH.I really recommend the game for people that are looking for a very tactical approach on a top-down shooter that recquires tons of teamplay with a very tough difficulty.The only two downsides for me are:It takes plenty of time to "learn the ropes" due to the lack of a good tutorial. You are pretty much required to ask other players for good class setups and fitting playstyles. It took my about a dozen times with some random teammates to see the victory screen the first time.The second one is no fault of the game and the reason for me to write that review: The Red Solstice has a pretty low player base and you can be sitting in the lobby for 15 minutes untill you find a game. I hope the playerbase grows stronger over time.The upside of that is a very nice and patient playerbase though.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a full-game version of the highly-rated Undead Assault games from the Starcraft II Arcade. Overall pretty fun, with lots of marines, missions, and monsters. If you haven't played UA, the premise is basically a squad-based survival horror. You run around, collect items, ammo, and weapons, and try to survive the onslaught of monsters while completing missions and helping your team mates. Solid overall premise and good execution here.The community seems pretty quiet lately, though, and it's hard to get a full game together at times. I think this title would probably work better as F2P with a well thought out microtransaction model and some weekly events, since there would be more people online.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first bought this game months ago, I will admit that it was in bad shape. Poor graphics optimization made the game nearly unplayable, with frame rates regularly reaching intolerable lows.Fast forward to today, and things have greatly improved. The game is a satisfying blend of RTS and action, and it really does perfectly capture that sort of panicky scoot-and-shoot flavor of sci-fi horror films in a way that other more visible/mainstream games haven't. Team-work is essential, but not forced.Currently the game is facing a major problem, though. In order to complete a scenario (that is, not die while frantically holing up in a building/deathtrap as ammo supplies dwindle) and complete objectives, you really do need a team of 6-8 players. And, sadly, the game is dying. Which is a real shame because it's fun and has greatly improved since its early mis-steps.If this goes on sale for anything 15.00 or lower, consider buying this game. It really is a unique and action-packed romp. It is in need of some more polishing which, if the player base doesn't completely dry up, will no doubt come along.

content:

Early Access Review
								A thinking man's top-down survival/shooter.I heavily recommend that this game be played by friends/people willing to voice chat with each other, as coordination (establishing "supply depots", sharing ammo/items, maintaining fire discipline [ammo is freaking SCARCE except in bunker defense], designating runners for objectives/activating turrets/points) is absolutely VITAL.While the learning curve is certaintly comparable with Dark Souls (I'm being serious, it's easy once you know what to do but one hell of a struggle to getting there), it is just as fun once you get into it. Unlike Dark Souls, I actually recommend looking up a few guides on basic strategy (target in light = good, target in dark = good luck hitting the broadside of a barn), as the game is not enjoyable if the player has no clue what to do (in which case they can very well drag down the entire team)
