content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												UPDATE 9/21/2015: I played this game a few weeks ago after quite some time, and was really pleased to find that they'd improved it. It's still incredibly hard, but that just makes winning even sweeter once you finally manage to do it. At only 20 bucks, I'd definitely reccommend this game. Unfortunately, I don't have any actual friends to play this with, so I'm left having to find pubs, but when I last played, there seemed to still be a pretty decent player base, and I only encountered one or two really trolly players. There seems to have been a clear movement towards discouraging people from going all Platoon on each other, which I personally really appreciate.9/10___________________________________ORIGINAL REVIEW:I can't wait to see the finished product this game turns into; I've really enjoyed myself in the missions available so far. While there isn't a lot of story or maps, yet, this game shows incredible promise. It's got a bit of a learning curve at first, and the difficulty continues to ramp up pretty consistently, but if you enjoyed Dawn of War, I think this may be a game for you. You only get control of one character, but the customization is pretty decent. The game could definitely benefit from added weapons or some kind of weapon-mod system, but there's a pretty good variety so far. All in all, I'd give the game about a 7/10 right now, if it were completed. Taking into consideration it's an early access game, I'd have to ammend that score to a 9/10. With a few improvments/additions, I'd be too busy playing this game to even write this review.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												I'm 3.7 hours into Red Solstice and the more I play, the more I like it. Not exactly an easy learning curve, and I was very close to going for a refund a couple times during the first mission.  Tutorial wasn't bad, but didn't cover many things that would have been pretty helpful as a newbie, things that I had to discover on my own.  Now, having done that I'm greatly enjoying it and would probably rate it an 8 out of 10 at this point. Still, having been a computer gamer for many years, I've learned that one doesn't really know the true 'staying power' of any game until you've played it for a week or two.  I would encourage anyone who gets frustrated in the early going to keep at it. You absolutely need to use the Tactical Mode a LOT to keep yourself alive.  In Tactical mode you can gain true control over your team, so, for example, you can give direct orders for 3 of your team to cover the one who's deploying satchels or resonators instead of relying on autoaim to protect you.  You can manuever much more effectively, and you also get a more personal feeling about each of your teammates when you're controlling them directly. One key thing (at least for me) that I didn't figure out until my third attempt at the first mission is that the GDD device not only points you to nearby monster spawn sites, it also points you to nearby resonators, which you must have to destroy the spawn sites. Without a resonator when you need it, the spawn sites will just continually churn out mobs, and the more functioning spawn sites, the more mobs until eventually you die a horrid, screaming death.So use the GDD to find the resonators and you'll find survival isn't really impossible.Good luck, and if this has the kind of staying power I think it will, my only complaint may be that there aren't enough single player missions to keep me happy, so I'll hope for some DLC in the not too distant future.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ever heard of SWAT:Aftermath? No? How about Starcraft 1 custom maps? No? ... then darn I'll have to explain if not I've probably already sold it to you.if you've never heard of SWAT:Aftermath or never played those Starcraft1 custom maps you might've missed out. However this is reminiscent of a future more developed version of that.(with greater technology of course!) Where you get to play as certain classes with certain skills and attributes utilizing different weapons and strategies you go around a huge map exploration-wide with buildings you can enter and exit along with power systems that can be activated or simply go looting around and making sure you destroy "radiation" blobs around the map or activating radar sensors and setting up fort for an oncoming onslaught upon your squad and simply surviving until rescue or you're overrun and slaughtered. There are of course other game modes like mission mode completing a series of missions storyline based or just task based. Another mode would be bunker mode which is defending a fort area. Survival is simply try to do the main missions in time, get out alive within 15 waves, brutally hard and requires quite a bit of coordination.And by squad I mean you and your friends. This game is thrilling with friends and co-op is abundant. What's better is your classes can level up there's equipment to unlock, and multiple difficulties and game modes being developed. The graphics are nice and I can't wait for further updates.There is no single player campaign quite yet due to it being in development, however multiplayer and the prologue mission is available and there's quite a bit to do already.Enemies range anywhere from parasites to gargantuan behemoths the size of a building.This is written during the game's alpha.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok so .. The Red Solstice .. apart from the really not great lobby and the 'we shall disconnect and crash the game - also for fun please redo the tutorial level before you're allowed to play multiplayer' problem, this is hard to fault. Think of space marines in any the following flavours: Warhammer/AVP/StarCraft and you'll be close to the kind of trooper feel the game has. You play one character and gain XP in 3 areas. The first is your XP (your account XP maybe) which gives you greater access to classes, weapons and perks as you progress. The second is your class XP - thus if you play medic alot you will unlock class specific 'powers'. The third is in-game XP - you start at the same basic level each new match and level within that match in a fashion similar to Dota or LoL etc. At the end of the match you lose that progression, but hey it's all good.Within the match there are items to be found. You only have 6 inventory slots so choose well and ammo is in short supply so it pays to grab it when you can and share with your team. Visually the game owes a lot to the Diablo 2 / Titans Quest / Warhammer view and it does look great, plus there is a lot of screen you cannot see due to poor lighting. Within buildings there are consoles which activate lights and flares which can be fired or dropped to help further. Also there are ad hoc sentry gun positions you can activate and within bunker mode, the option to deploy 'reinforcement' sentry turrets periodically.think i have done all i can to describe this game - noe go watch a youtube video on it

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
Product received for free
Review On the store page you'll read "Survive on Mars. Or die trying."Well, get ready to die. A lot.The planet Earth has been decimated and part of the human race is trying to survive on Mars.After a storm called "The Red Solstice", the Tharsis colony has lost communication with the other humanc olonies of Mars. A squad of marines is sent to find out what happened to the colony.The Red Solstice is a top-down, tactical, squad based survival shooter video game with RPG elements.There are three game modes: Single-player (Campaing), Survival and Multiplayer.On Single-player (Campaing) you control a squad of 4 marines through 10 missions. The first two missions serve as a tutorial, teaching you the basic controls and how to play.There are 4 difficulty levels.At the beginning of each mission you can choose the class of your marine, his primary and secondary weapon and up to 4 skills. However, you start with the Assault class only. The other classes and weapons will be unlocked as you progress on single-player missions.The game has a good variety of enemies and weapons.While playing solo you can use the Tactical Mode, where you press a button and the game runs 90% slower so you can issue orders/change the strategy/change the players position.In the beginning it's important to focus in one or two skills. Don't try to keep all of the skills at the same level.Also, it's important to have a balanced squad of various classes.And get ready to die. It's possible to revive a dead squad member, but if all of them die, you'll have to restart from the last checkpoint.The Survival mode it's like the multiplayer mode, but you play with bots, just like in single-player.There are random missions and events, 6 different maps, you can also level up and unlock new classes and abilities.In the Multiplayer mode you can play co-op with up to 8 players, in random missions and events, 6 different maps, you can also level up and unlock new classes and abilities.Currently there are few people playing this mode, so it may be hard to find someone to play with.Rating:9/10For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit Steamified[www.steamified.com]

Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Gunnery Sergeant Alex PortsvilleCURRENT EMPLACEMENT: Search & Rescue, Tarsonis.Information class: Need to know, non-classified.04:32 AM, Central Sector: Tarsonis.Ground drop sucsessfull, proceeding with main objective. So far no signs of any colonists. The lights are out, it's like walking into your own grave. A certain chill lingers in the air, like the crackle in the air after an onslaught.04:34 AM, Central Sector, Power plant: Entrance hallThe walls are covered in slime and debris, half rotten corpses lies swatted around. Some are hanging from the ducts of the roof, body parts and gore litter the floor with countless bullet shells. We counted 4 different types of ammo, possibly survivors. 04:35 AM, Central Sector, Power plant: FacilitiesScratch that, 3 survivors. Located the source of the shotgun shells. Poor sod blew his brains out on the bathroom. Door was smashed halfway inn so we couldnt get to the corpse.Power node was smahed up good, somebody must have driven a pneumatic cargo lifter into it. That hole in it was scary big.04:47 AM, Central Sector, C-Sec Brig.Nobody home, weapons rack cleaned out save for some road flares and a pack of shotgun cartridges.The cell housing look to have been blown up partially, 6 of the 12 cells are completely destroyed. The remaining 6 were all covered with pulsating green mass. Tray, our medic pulled us out as his sensors picked up a build up of lethal gas. 04:53 AM, Central Sector, PlazaThe place was swarmed with... things. they were covering the floor to wall with gore, slime and god knows what else. One of the two legged "infected" was wearing a C-Sec uniform. We lost Mike, our heavy support on the retreat out.Somebody ♥♥♥♥ed up bad here, and T.A.R.A ain't telling♥♥♥♥♥♥We hear them skittering around, screeching. Sometimes a loud thump can be heard, as if buildings are collapsing.*SIGNAL LOST, CONSULT T.A.R.A FOR IMMEDIATE RECOVERY*05:38 AM, Central Sector, OutskirtsEverybodys gone. They swarmed the entire sector, we ran out of bullets fairly quickly. I... I ran and sealed the exit, locking them in with the rest of them. They seem to have bought me enough time to get out.The sector is burning, I've picked up a few signals on the radio here and there. Nobody stays on long enough for contact, or they stay on long enough to scream in agony.The infected are moving, as if with a cause around. Sometimes i see a behemoth with them, dragging debris the size of small tanks after them. They... They organize the infected, sending out scout squadrons.I don't think i'll see the sun rise...*User has manually disconected from uplink*

content:
Posted: January 15
Product received for free
The Red SolsticeThe Red Solstice is an isometric sci-fi tactical shooter.The story revolves around a group of four space marines deployed to an area of Mars that has basically gone dark and seems to be attacked by unknown forces.Upon arrival they find an infestation of aggresives aliens and other problems that have decimated the area.Your job is to lead the squad to find out what is happening and put a stop to it.GRAPHICSGraphically the game is nothing to write home about.A lot of areas are very dark and the general quality of the graphics feel a couple generations old.While the gunfire effects are pretty nice and vivid, everything else, from explosions to hit effects and lighting feels very low rent and subpar.This looks like a game that would have been high-end graphically maybe 10 years ago at best.Animations aren't as fluid as they could be and the entire graphical experience feels like a game made with a indie gamemaker tool and does not compete with similair games of the genre.GAMEPLAYGameplay is keyboard and mouse control.Right click to move, left to fire/activate/etc.The gameplay is split into realtime mode, where you control one squad member, and tactical mode which is a super slowed down (90% slower) mode where you can control any of the squad members, give them commands, and upgrade their functions. Control of your squad is very basic.Follow, Fire and Stay Put are basically what you have to work with.Although each squad member has his own upgradable paths, they are all the same options and  they don't seem to be very varied regardless and the game does a poor job at explaining what each option does.The small text over each upgrade option only gives a very basic idea of what the upgrade is for and makes it hard to decide if you should bother using the upgrade points on each selection.There is a way to directly control the main guy you start with by holding down (SHIFT), you can point and click at an object and fire.However, no matter how accurate it said my shot would be, it was very random as to how effective my shot actually was.The whole manual control is made pointless by an Auto-Aim mode that is activated by hitting E in realtime mode.Basically auto-aim has each squad member (yourself included) automatically aim and fire on any threat.I feel the auto-aim feature is way too powerful as it takes 80% of the gameplay out of the players hands and the manual mode isn't a good answer as it is too unperdictable to use effectivivly.There needs to be more control in shooting.Hitting a bad guy in the head should be devasting, rather than it is now where you just spray and pray and hitting a guy 15 times in the foot is just as effective as 15 times in the gut or the head.The shooting feels weak and inconsitant and enemies are massive bullet sponges.The rest of the gameplay is your cliched sci-fi something-has-gone-wrong-at-station-blah-blah-blag fetch quest.Go here, activate or find this, go there and do that and then fight off the wave of enemies that pop-up as you enter a new area. Rinse and repeat.The tactical mode is the only real ray of sunshine in an otherwise dull twinstick style shooter.By placing your units in key areas they act as defensive lineman to guard areas you need covered while you flip switches and read PDA logs.AUDIOAudio is pretty standard audio, with a macho sounding guy telling his other squadies what they need to do, and how they go about doing it.None of the audio logs have any voice overs, and other than ingame cutscenes, your character is the only one that makes much noise.Your squadmate characters are forgettable as they never speak and you know virtually nothing about them other than their upgrade stats.PROSThe "tactical" mode is a nice idea.Slowing down time by 90% and giving you control of all members is great for this type of game and is the only thing about the game I could really find to enjoy.CONSBeing an isometric game, there are times when things are hidden behind objects, I could not find a way to rotate the screen and objects would be hard to see because of a blocking wall or debris.If you are going to make your screen none rotatable, don't hide stuff behind other objects or near the edge of blocking walls!Graphically game is sub-par and feels generations behind other offerings in the genre.The story is a cliche "super soldiers sent to planet x because: aliens" trope and feels flimsy.The player doesn't have much direct control and the game feels like it plays itself most of the time.RATINGRating in this Genre is a 5 out of 10.A very basic attempt with it's only saving grace is the tactical mode.Rating for games in general is a 4 out of 10.For the asking price of this game, there are many other choices out there that will give a better experience.If the game was 75% off or better I would say "maybe", otherwise, it is not worth the retail asking price by a long shot.FINAL THOUGHTSI love the idea of a keyboard and mouse isometric shooter, and the tactical slow mode is a nice feature, but the shooting and feeling of any control based on player skill just isn't there.There doesn't seem to be any robustness to the gunplay either.After awhile each encounter with an enemy just feels like an annoyance as your squad mates just automatically do the most appropriate thing and easily dispatch the enemy while you run around fetching supplies or pushing buttons.I had to try really hard to fail (on normal difficulty).There is very little strategy, other than placing your squad mates in the right spot to take out incoming enemies, there isn't much else to it.The story just feels old and overdone and I quickly lost interest it what I was there for.Bad guys here, go kill them, then flip a switch is basically what it boils down to in the end, which can be fun if done right.If the gameplay itself is fun, it can trump the story, but if both are medicore, then you have a problem.Take the 2016 DOOM reboot as an example.Sure, the story there has been done a thousand times, but the polish and the meat of the combat felt good and solid.Here, everything feels weak and unpolished.There is just nothing new or novel about any of this game other than the slowed down tactical mode which is not enough to save this game.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I picked up my rifle and stepped out of the dropship into the dark unknown, my boots caked in red dust and dried blood. The corpses of the team sent here before us were strewn all over the area. I could already tell, this was going to be a long mission.If it’s not demons plaguing your usual trip to the Red Planet, then it must be aliens. Welcome to The Red Solstice, a Steam Early Access title developed by Ironward and published by Nkidu Games, Inc. The Red Solstice is a tactical top-down action shooter with an emphasis on teamwork and survival. The general story revolves around you and your team of space marines exploring what remains of human civilization on Mars after a massive storm (named the “Red Solstice”) has nearly wiped out all power and communications on the planet. At the same time, a large collection of alien lifeforms have emerged seeking to kill everything they see. Graphically, it seemed okay. The art design depicted a very dark and gritty sci-fi world, which I liked. What annoyed me slightly was just dark some of the levels were, though. At times, it became slightly difficult to see where exactly I was going. On another note, the various types of aliens you fight looked pretty cool. My main concern though, lies once again in the controls, namely, the camera.In Red Solstice, the camera has a bad habit of not following your player at all, meaning you have to not only constantly direct your character on where to go, but you also need to manage keeping the camera on them at all times. Combine that with the fact that you and your allies will be getting attacked constantly by enemies, and things can get hectic pretty quickly. To make matters worse, the camera isn’t locked to the application’s window. So, if you happen to be playing in windowed mode (like I was), and your cursor happens to drift outside of the game for a second or two by accident, the camera will end up showing you what’s going on about five miles to your left instead of what’s currently gnawing your kneecaps off.Multiplayer has some interesting class choices, ranging from your standard assault troopers with machine guns, to people who go around wielding flamethrowers, looking to make a quick barbeque dinner out of their enemies. It also seems to contain its own separate campaign missions, which is pretty cool.At the time of writing, there are seven available game modes. Hardcore Mode spawns boss monsters randomly with each wave, and you gain a bit more XP with each kill. The Primary and Secondary Missions modes are the story missions for multiplayer. Fast Mode makes all of the enemies significantly faster, though slightly weaker. Red Storm mode reduces your armor over time, and you’re noticeably slower when not inside buildings. You also take more damage from bullets while inside buildings. You do get a nice chunk of extra XP for your trouble, though. With Swarm mode, you get a bit of zombie apocalypse thrown in with your alien infestation, as there are a LOT more zombies. Thankfully, they’re also slightly weaker than normal. Finally, there is the currently being worked on “Bunker” mode, where players must protect some sort of object known as the Orbital Beacon. There are two other modes, but they are currently greyed out, so I assume they’re not ready yet. For the sake of trying to explain what they might be, I’m just going to go off of what they’re described as in-game. “Random Waves” mode features “completely randomized waves based on pre-defined types of wave groups,” and “Point Capture” mode involves the players capturing a series of points inside the map by defending the points from oncoming waves of enemies.There is also a nice levelling system implemented, with there being a maximum of 25 achievable ranks, complete with unlockable weapons and perks. As you gain higher ranks, the stats of your character also increase over time. Weapons are pretty standard as well for a sci-fi game. Machine guns, energy pulse rifles, flamethrowers, shotguns, grenade launchers. Nothing too out of the ordinary. You can also add small, but balanced power-ups to your characters fully customizable load-out, which allow you to do things like reload your weapon faster, make your armor stronger, or do more damage. On top of everything, the game also seems to hold future promises of a singleplayer campaign, which I think could be pretty interesting.As for the sound, much like the graphics, there isn’t much to say. Guns go bang, aliens screech and growl. It’s all pretty standard stuff. The voice acting was also pretty average. One very minor complaint here, adjusting the volume levels in the settings seemed a little weird. You don’t actually hear any changes you make until AFTER you’ve saved and left the menu.Personally, I found this game to be a little too run-of-the-mill for me. It’s by no means a bad game, but right now there really isn’t anything to it that makes it stand out from anything else to me. But, if this looks like a game you would be interested in, then by all means check it out. The Red Solstice is currently available for purchase on Steam for $19.99.http://wtbfun.com/the-red-solstice-an-early-look/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												It’s been two years, so I figured I’d take another crack at what there is to say about The Red Solstice…This kickstarter game, birthed from Starcraft and Warcraft mods, NOTD or Night Of The Dead has come a long way. It's a top down, action based, strategy, horror, survival game, where you control a single soldier, in a group of 1-8 players fighting against waves of monstrous AI controlled enemies. There are options to play with a player controlled team of 3 semi-intelligent marines, but the meat of the game comes from the live co-op play. Over the past few months of playing, I can clearly see that the game has gotten a lot better. I’ve tried to touch on the major categories that I personally feel like need to be addressed in this follow up review of the game, specifically the balance, the community, the controls, and the content. This review is critical and doesn’t cover all of the better points of the game, but addresses many of the issues that were the major detractors of the game upon my first review.  BALANCEThe difficulty rankings have four stages from an easy mode for new players,to the bleeding edge hard mode for those who have sunk in well over 200 hours of gameplay with maxed out suits. The game balancing has been tweaked to make playing the game reasonable at entry level, but maintains a challenge into the harder modes. Regardless, without a solid team, the chance of survival on normal (soldier) difficulty is still pretty low. The learning curve in the game is steep!  Developing 'run away skills' and learning from tactical errors (death), comes with time - more objectives completed, enemies killed and a successfully evac results in appropriate bonuses. There are no dead weight classes once you become proficient, which is nice to see as well. Some vets and more experienced players may try to build specific teams to their meta, but there are no classes that are never worth taking, which brings me to my next topic.COMMUNITYThis really needs to be addressed based on the very small player base of this game. There are a few great players that are helpful, nice and can make the game great to play. Without naming any names, there was one community member with over a thousand hours who found me when I re-joined the game and was very forward in wanting to provide a positive experience coming back into the game. I have seen a select few work towards raising up new players and helping them with their suit builds and laying out a plan in game to win. They lead by example and remain positive providing a genuinely high quality experience. That being said, some people are cancer. A few veteran players in particular are unchecked malignant growths that have been hanging on for far too long. One example in particular, let’s call him “Lord D-Bag” intentionally fragged a team member without warning because he believed that the team member wasn’t playing to Lord D-Bag’s chosen meta. What followed was a verbal fight and unapologetically run the team into the ground ending in a team loss.This behavior is unacceptable. Veteran players who dictate instead of leading has been a serious problem with the game since the game’s inception. I was happy to see a few friends who I used to play with re-join to have players like Lord D-Bag rudely talk down to them without insight, resulting in a lost player. This mentality of “my house, my rules” has created a small player base, and has limited the game since it's inception. I have to say, fortunately, that these players are now in the minority, but it is something to be aware of and to avoid. If you’ve ever played a game online late in the life cycle, none of this is new, but remember!: Positivity breeds positivity. CONTROLSI tell people, whenever I try to explain this game, that TRS is very reminiscent of StarCraft. It’s like taking a Terran Marine and stripping away all of the base building and having a lone marine weather the Zerg. For those who don’t understand the reference, it’s a game of precision. Many slight movements with precise clicks can make all of the difference. A self induced death is just as easy as getting killed by an enemy with a poorly placed explosive, or a missed healing. The skill hotkeys and team movement commands are straightforward. The issues come from the crappy hotkeys for the game items in your character's inventory and trying to control an AI team. When things get heated, you don’t want to accidentally hit the wrong hotkey combination and deploy a tactical nuke instead of a medkit, and it’s startlingly easy to do. This leads to having to click in the inventory to use every item. That’s not the worst thing, but it’s far from convenient. When it comes to controlling AI when you’re playing a solo game, the controls are the same as setting guidelines for a team in multiplayer. You can press the spacebar to go into a “tactical mode” which slows down time and allows you to click on the other character’s banner to directly control them like you would your own character. The problem comes from trying to control the other semi-AI characters when you have another player. The standard controls completely change for whatever reason. Without getting into the details of all of the flaws, let's just say the semi-AI requires a lot of micromanagement, with the memory of a goldfish and no tactical mode to help sort it out. This is exceptionally difficult to manage when you’re in the heat of battle and you need to precision to stay alive. This underlines the requirement playing multiplayer with people ONLY, or singleplayer survival with the AI team ONLY. Difficult.CONTENTThe amount of content in the game has increased quite a bit in the past few years. Now it has a story driven single-player mode which is focused on plot events leading up to the story of the multiplayer mode. After a single pass on story mode, (which is all you’ll want to do) the game will boil down to its multi-player focus. There are a decent number of maps to play on, which are decently well designed and balanced with their own individual perks and difficulties. There are a lot of customizable multiplayer modes including defending a bunker, killing insurgents, collecting data entries, destroying alien pods and others, with additional modifiers. All of these come  on the back of a waved survival mode. There are also a hand full of different suits your character can wear including a few stand outs like a marksman who has a extremely potent rail gun, a heavily armed demolition class, energy weapon / teleportation specialist terminator and others. They are all unique and have their own perks and uses, though some skills feel underpowered while others are must haves. As stated in the community portion, some players will tell you to change if they find that your build isn't what they want, but in the end, it’s all based on how you like to play, and there are plenty of options to cater to your whim.CONCLUSIONThough this game has some flaws, I personally enjoy the game. I've put in 360+ hours at the time of this review, over 150 more since my first. At this time I’ve maxed out all of my suits abilities and am able to reach the final wave of survival by myself, but I still haven’t maxed out my maximum proficiency (rank). I still have awards to win and higher goals to conquer. As a new player, online guides are available to help get you started, and there are helpful players who can get you proficient in no time. It’s also nice to see that the developers are still on board, hosting Tournaments and keeping the community live! I am happy to recommend this game to my friends and get them engaged. I think it would be great to bring in new players and breathe some new life into this game.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												So being that I was a fan of Alien Swarm, I decided to pick this game up. So far I have been very pleasantly surprised about every aspect of the game.Graphics-wise it isn't the best, but it doesn't look so bad that it is unplayable. It isn't anything like modded Skyrim, but it has it's charms. There is in-game physics, though it doesn't affect gameplay. If your marine walks across something that should be "kickable" it will move. Kind of impressive in my own opinion.Gameplay is where this game shines. It seems fairly straightforward at first, but I think it combines the best micro of a MOBA with the frantic pace of Left 4 Dead. There are times at the end of a game where you are running away in a panic as you are being pursued by far too many enemies to fight, but if you are smart and quick you may be able to pull off a victory. In addition the customization offered in character selection is surprisingly in depth. There are 8 distinct classes, plenty of weapons, different selectable abilities for each class, and small modifiers that make feeling your own particular play style out a necessity. Guides may offer a helpful nudge towards success, but ultimately you can play pretty much any way you want and still be successful, as long as you work well with your team.Finally the community. There aren't that many people online as of right now (July 14, 2015). One would think this might create a barrier to playing, but everyone seems super friendly and helpful. There are games starting up every 30 seconds or so, and while you may not have that many to choose from right now you shouldn't have any problems with a pickup game. In addition the dev team is very active with the community. My second night playing multiplayer I saw a game titled "dev game" or something like that. I hopped in not expecting much, but the damn main developer of the game was the host. He was consistently asking players if they were having any problems with a recent patch, and seemed to really care about making a game that was good, not just a game that will make a profit.All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to everyone on Steam. Not just because it is fun, but because the people involved with it actually give a damn about making games. If you care about the PC gaming industry, this is the type of game you need to support.9.9/10 There is always room for improvement.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This is a great game, but not for everyone. I have only played the MP mode, and the game shows a lot of replayability, intensity, and teamwork moments. In MP, you control a single marine (usually) as you complete random missions with teammates. The point of the game is to complete as many missions and objectives as possible and then call for EVAC - before getting overrun. There can be up to 8 players in a single game, and each player can select the type of suit (class) and equipment they are taking on the mission. Classes range from Marksman, which is a sniper type of role, to Medics, Demolitions, Flamethrower, etc. The classes are varied, and have different upgrades which allows them to fulfill different roles.And that is what the game is all about - cooperation! As time goes on the enemy gets stronger and more numerous, supplies will run low, and people will start to die. Every moment becomes a tactical decision, and the smallest misstep can spell doom.  The enemy AI is not particularly clever, which is important because funnelling enemies into explosive death traps becomes very important, specially when you are facing one of the game's bosses.Death is painful, because there is no respawns - except for new players. If you are not a new player (determined by some threshold of character XP), then you stay dead until a medic can revive you or a special mission ("Reinforcements") is completed by the team. (This mission becomes available about halfway through the game, and its availability by no means guarantees that you will be able to complete it!)The graphics and sounds are mediocre at best, functional at least. The music is slightly better. They will not turn you away from the game, but the game wont win any awards for any of these.Playing with friends is where its at - the game has a lot to explore, and that means a lot of death and discovery as you come to grips with the game. The game does have built in voice, and there is also a public TeamSpeak server which sees a lot of action. The community is friendly overall, and it is tight knight as is common with communities that form around hidden gems like this game.There seems to be a good amount of replayability - first because the game is HARD, second because of how missions are randomized. There are I think 6 maps total, but everyone is still playing the first (and easiest!) of these. I actually thought at first that there was only one map and that it was randomly generated. And this is because the maps are very large, and there is so much going on, that it took a few days before I realized map is not random.I got the game 48 hours ago and have not been able to stop playing it. It is a real nail-biting experience, the cooperative aspects works really well, and the community is there to support it and help it grow.All we need is you now!

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I consider myself a veteran of many "squad-based run-and-gun shooters" like this one. After all, The Red Solstice is based off of games like Night of the Dead and Undead Assault II, which are some notable maps/mods for another game called Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne -- a title I've sunk more than 8 years of my time into.With such a "veteran's perspective" on the genre, does The Red Solstice live up to the hype? In my opinion, yes, it actually does. The developers have succeeded in making an enjoyable game that stays faithful to the source material that inspired it, while doing plenty to make it stand out from the crowd. Let me just give you a short and sweet rundown on some of the core features that interested me:-----1.) A light system. Whether it be due to the titular storm that is the game's namesake, or simply that your mission takes place at night, every playable map in the game is cast in darkness, broken by streetlights, burning flares left by your team, fires from ignited fuel barrels, and interior lights that you have to reactivate by finding their central power stations in different buildings. If you are shooting at a target in dim or no light, you are penalized with a substantial chance for your bullet to miss and be wasted. If firing on enemies in bright light, like the brilliant radiance of a Flare Gun item, you can expect near-100% accuracy (if you're standing still and shooting).And sometimes? Sometimes, by random event or by a failed mission, the lights in your sector will go dark. That makes it a damn inconvenient time to have to fight off a wave of mutants threatening to chew your face off, because the lights emitted by your suit only extend a few meters in a circle around you. If the light isn't enough to make out enemies approaching you, all you will see in the shadows is rapidly-moving shapes, accentuated by guttural roars from the beasts who can track you like a lantern in a coal mine. Without adequate light, your ammo efficiency, accuracy, and overall combat effectiveness will drop like a lead brick.2.) A leader/officer system. At the start of the game, you get to designate a maximum of 2 players (from an 8-player squad) to be Leaders. These players get access to special key commands that let them set waypoints and routes for the team, which show up as bright yellow lines on the minimap that are easily followed. Leaders are also the only ones who can access certain game-changing items and features, like the Safety Zone, which is a beacon that calls down fresh ammo and supplies, as well as a sustained orbital artillery barrage in a circle around the beacon while leaving the beacon itself (and, hopefully, you) untouched. Thus, you won't have to worry about some trolling player activating a full-charge Safety Zone without the rest of their team, or running ahead and turning it on and getting the team killed by artillery.3.) Throwable explosive barrels. No, I am not kidding. Each player has the ability to right-click fuel or toxic material barrels, have their marine/character pick them up, and then hurl them about twenty meters wherever you left-click the mouse. This is AMAZING for area denial, as chucking a few barrels into a narrow corridor can wipe out hordes of zombies with the damage-over-time fire patches or toxin clouds they leave when they explode. Doing this does cost you 30 armor points (you start with ~100 but can get more), though, so you should make sure your shots count.NOTE:  There is a flamethrower-using class in this game that gets an ability which lets him use fuel and toxin barrels to provide ammo for his weapon. Not only that, it juices his flamer to where it now leaves the same clouds the exploding barrels do. xD4.) Dismountable turrets. Sentry turrets exist around the map, which you can either spend time activating one-by-one or, if you're lucky, find a central terminal that'll turn them all on. Once active you can "disarm" them (with the right tools/skills), turning them into a dismounted turret that you can then place virtually anywhere on the ground you please. So not only do you get to save turrets in a bad spot from certain destruction, you also get to use them to build your own defensive positions! ^^5.) A nice, streamlined explosives system. A good percentage of the items you'll find throughout a given game will be satchel charges, incendiaries, claymore mines, plasma bombs, and directional primer charges. In case you don't know what the latter is, it's a "leap bomb" that scatters a shotgun-like cone-shaped blast of high explosives in whatever direction it's pointed, which is helpfully indicated by red lines so you don't blow your team up by accident. Very lethal to tight groups charging down a narrow hallway.Anyway, the system. Many explosives in this game are external-source-only, which means you have to supply an initial explosion (like a grenade or rocket) to set them off. Some are radio-detonated, like satchel charges or the aforementioned directional primer charges, and need only a quick double-tap of the "G" key (by default) to set off. You can disarm most explosives at will if you need to move them or just don't want them anymore, as long as you have the right tools or skills available (the Demolitions class is the best at this). Since you really need the firepower of high explosives to have any real hope of surviving the late-game waves of tough enemies (I nearly got overrun even after dropping a tactical nuke on half a wave), it's really nice to have a system that demands so little micromanagement. You don't have to click the bomb or anything like you might in some other games.-----The Red Solstice does have its own fair share of issues, like some wireframe-y animations on certain enemies when they attack, and poor or outright inaccurate documentation on weapons and abilities, but nothing that really turns me off or makes it so that it's chafing to play the game. I mean, I come from Warcraft 3, and that game is old as dirt by comparison to today's titles, so a few little things like that actually endear me to the game even more. The Red Solstice has a pretty respectable soundtrack, too, with solid themes all the way from the main menu to the combat suit selection screen to the final, desperate run for the evacuation dropship while the area is crawling with monsters at the end of the mission.All in all? Yes, I think The Red Solstice might just be a winner. If you like fast-paced, run-and-gun squad-based gameplay, or want to feel like you're Space Marines from Warhammer 40k fighting off a Tyranid infestation, this will find a welcome home on your shelf.I give The Red Solstice a solid 8.5/10! The reason it's not higher is because the documentation for the game really is that bad -- they neglect to mention that the Precise Fire skill passively increases your movement speed, NOT your health regeneration, for example. I'm trying to fix that by editing the unofficial Red Solstice wiki, but in-game, you just kinda have to play for a while to figure this stuff out. Still, recommended!

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												"Real-time X-Com" is an apt description.Bought it for the mp, but the single-player campaign is extremely well done.  In mp you only control one character while giving simple follow/stay commands to rescued AI marines.  In single-player you utilize bullet-time pause to fully control squads.  You'll decide which characters to bring with you on a mission, outfit them, and level them.  The degree of replayability is high, since each character levels separetely, while belonging to one of eight classes.  You're encouraged to attempt missions with different class combos, which will completely change your tactics and playstyle - this keeps things fresh.Two characters of the same class can be built differently by altering their stats, powerups, abilities and gear (all of which you find as loot during missions).  I have one assault character built as a speedy, evasive, melee expert, used for hit-run bombing alien spawn tunnels.  I have another specializing in grenade AOE support, and another as a pseudo-sniper marksman who holds the mid-line.SP feels a lot like Dawn of War 2's campaigns during realtime, but the slo-mo pause gives it a tactical X-com feel. You'll also get overrun and die easily even on normal difficulty, just like classic X-com. Even though you only control one character in MP, things are even hairier than they are in SP, since there's no pause. The easiest "recruit" difficulty will slaughter many players.  I just finished my first "recruit" difficulty multiplayer mission at 27h (though much of it was spent in single-player).I'm having a blast with it.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								So I haven't beaten the first map yet, in 24 hours of playing. Do I recommend it? **ck yeah!First things first, I still consider myself as a noob at this because I very rarely (if at all) play comparable games. To me, the game was very overwhelming at first (in a bad way). I was confused by the fairly complex game mechanic and the very stiff learning curve. I didn't know what to do and when I learned what I had to do, I didn't know how.On the one hand that might be because of my lack of experience with games like this and on the other hand because of the lack of a decent tutorial (which is an issue the devs want to work on). There is a small one but it does only explain the very basics. Further more you need a capable team.But if you keep playing despite of that, you'll start enjoying this game a lot. You rank up in total and additionally with each class. Promotions in any of those two ranks unlock new gear, components (skills) and passive bonuses (Even if you do not win the map or finish all missions... or get to the emergency evac). I played only medic so far and didn't reached the highest rank with it yet, and there are about 8 classes to rank up with, so that keeps you motivated for a while if you are into stuff like that.Once you learned about controls, enemies, missions, gear, friendly fire and classes you will become usefull for your team, which is great. It is fun to see your own progress and reaching higher waves and more difficult goals while getting better. And even if don't make it, you still made progress, because you earned xp and unlocked new stuff, which will make it easer the next time.On the downside we have the fact of TRS being in early access, which means you will run into bugs every now and then. So far I didn't had any that were too troubling, nothing that can't be fixt or made me stop playing. The community is yet small. You may not always find regional game lobbies but I was always able to find some games in the global lobby. Also does the game not offer that much for graphic enthusiasts. But as I said, I do recommend the game. After I got the hang of it I started to enjoy the helping, covering and healing, sharing of ammunition, in short: the teamwork.And despite of that, who is going to stop the horrors of mars, if not YOU(!)?I'm doing my part! What about YOU? You wanna live forever?!

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I enjoy this game a whole lot, and I feel like I will always enjoy and appreciate it more than people who just pick it up as a "cool looking game" due to the fact that it is basically a remake of the ye olde WarCraft 3 and StarCraft/StarCraft Broodwar survival custom maps you'd see on Battle.Net from time to time. The multiplayer for this one currently reminds me more of the Night of the Living Dead custom map from WarCraft 3, and let me tell you, they did a damn good job of it.It would be nice if the game locked the window to the screen though, often I find myself right clicking off on to my second monitor in intense situations which gets pretty frustrating (so locking to the primary monitor in use would be a nice feature devs <3 ), but aside from that and some controls that sometimes feel a little clunky (hey it's early access though so that isn't really a complaining point for me unless it doesnt get better at all with final release), this game is pretty amazing. I love the fact that they replicated even the small details, back in WarCraft 3 your group had it's own AI-like dialogue where when a character would say something their name and their ingame progression/rank would come up as who says it, and this game does it just perfectly, so for example, when an event occurs and my character talks it'll say "Private P-sychotic:" and then whatever dialogue is triggered via event. It might just be me feeling all nostalgic over WarCraft 3 Battle.net days, but I love that they've added this.Anyway regardless of this being an Early Access review, I would still rate it worth buying and immensely enjoyable, and somewhat nostalgic for the custom Battle.net map players out there. Currently there is only a prologue which is essentially a tutorial, and only multiplayer with the promise of singleplayer later on.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is difficult. Sure, you will get a few mission objectives.  And yes, you will kill a few dozen monsters.Around wave 3 the aliens might get lucky and catch your friend alone and/or unaware.You'll try to save him of course.  No man left behind.  But it was to late, and deep down you knew it.By wave 5 the aliens step up the challenge, sending giants after you.  It will break a team mate's leg and they will tell you to leave them behind.  He'll hold them off while you run.  You can hear his death cry as you leave him to die.Then, they will By wave 7 the stress is getting to you and the remainder of your team.  The aliens come in swarms now, the pack no longer strong enough.  The turrets are helping, but for how much longer?Wave 9 arrives.  You are low on ammo, medical supplies are scarce, and the objective is on the other side of the city.What member of your team goes next?  Is it you?  The heavy support?  The hellfire maybe?  Will someone sacrifice themselves to slow down the horde?  Will the horde even slow down as the few overtake and devour its next victim?Don't die with the weight of your last mistake on your soul.  Everyone makes mistakes.  And even if you do it perfectly, you are just a single part in a chain of events.  Who is to say that it was you directly that caused your entire team will die.... Do I recommend this game?  Yes.  Yes I do.  For now.  Early access is a far cry from the end product.The AI could use some fixes.  The monster ability to track you from anyplace to anyplace is a little annoying.  This means that they always know where you are.  You can't hide or lose them.  And they don't have to search for you to start with.The loot table could use a little fix too, some more ammo would be useful because they always know where you are.  Medical supplies seem ok for now, but I play with people who can drop supplies.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS THOUGHTS.Do you remember this map in Warcraft 3? Where you and other people play as a marine trying to survive in a city? Yeah, this game is basicly it on a new level. The game is good and decently optimized.But devs need to solve one thing ASAP: they need to figure out how to hold players in this game.Hear me out here. With this game in it current state devs will never be able to hold an average player for more than a 5-10 hours. And the rotation of players will be too small for this game to be populated. Devs need to make something for players to come back for, make game as random as possible.Best solution i see is making more random events. Making more rewards. Making more progression trackers. Making map being random or semi-random on each new play. Add more winning conditions, so players losing every game will not feel themselves drained and abandoned.I played 10 hours and i don't think there is something to come back for. Maybe once a week with a friend. Maybe. But thats not enough. How will they keep money flowing? I don not know. I just hope they will figure this out. Microtransactions on customization is something i could easily accept.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								As yet another NotD player, my review is obviously biaised. But listen on.TRS brings to the masses a genre in itself : Tactical Survival.If you think from the screenshots it looks like Alien Swarm or something, think again.It's not a game about being a gun-and-kite wizz -- you've got to keep thinking at every second or bad things will happen.Teamwork is at every corner: unless you know what you're doing, you /will/ die if you even split up the team.Everything goes down too fast for words: eventually a team of skilled players reach a symbiosis where just moving is enough to communicate.An armored rushes your team. Whole team spreads out. The flamer moves forward to protect. Move behind him. He's out of ammo and starts moving away. Move on the side and start firing to kite. The demolitions leader orders the team to move away. Sprint off in an arc toward them, Devourer tailing you. The Demo fires off his rocket launcher, missing you by half a meter and killing it. It's fine, he knows what he's doing. Move on.While not as hardcore as the old NotD maps (i highly recommend the SC2 remake of Spec Ops which is still almost better than TRS... hopefully not for long!), this game is still pretty hard. You will die, and die, and die again. Unless most of the team knows what to do. And even then, one person can screw up : and you'll be that person at some point. Learn. Retry.And as you get better and better, leveling up and stacking bonuses, you'll find the game itself gets harder. New things appear, sometimes subtle, but enough to make a big difference.All in all, if you like Zombies, Hardcore, fast-paced games, and Teamwork, i can only recommend this. The price might be a bit steep, and it takes a while to get used to -- but once you do, it's totally worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a really interesting tactical game. First of all, I don't recall playing a 8 players CO-OP in a long long time, so seeing a game that can accommodate a large group of friends together is almost an instant win.This game reminds me to Starcraft, well basically you control some Marines, but the top-view camera really does a good job to bring Starcraft memories to my head. NO just that!! after a few minutes you will be immerse in a mix of Shadowgrounds/Aliens/Alien Swarm/Warhammer 4K... really really interesting. The game require a lot of teamwork, since is really easy to get lost in the map and overrun by aliens, but the addition to marines classes helps a lot to maintain the troops alive.Controls are something that you need to get use to it, but is not anything from the other world, so in a few games you will be able to control your marine movements and shoot without any issues.Also there are perks and auto-aim that you can use, but everything comes with a cost, because you may need to sacrifice something in order to get that bonus. For example if you use Auto-aim for a few, during that time the character will move 20% slower. This is a really interesting aspect in the game, and make the customization of your character, before every mission, critical.I would recommend this game to anybody who loves games like Alien Swarm and enjoy tactical games.KAZ verdict:  7 out of 10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								10.1.2015 Early Access. As a friend of this genre, and a huge fan of NOTD. This is the game, also nice that the devs play with us, its mostly stable. Patches seem to be rolling in atleast once a week. Starting a game takes a bit patience, like 15minutes or so. Extremely challenging even for high rank players. hard difficulty is already totally insane. And there is Nightmare difficulty after that.Its starter friendly in every way, until you hit Rank8. There is some bugs and undeveloped systems, but not any gamebreakers. Mostly you get used to them and stop noticing them. 80% of the players i have played with are helpful and friendly. Learning not to die, playing as a team, micromanage your every move is the key to victory. There is two methods you can play and switch any time. Automove (or follow) + autofire, will cause you sometimes miss, reducing total DPS, but your instincts and reactions are sharp as a bot, Then there is manual mode. Swapping primary to secondary weapon you run 25% faster, switching from autofire mode to burstfire will enable you move fast between high damage shots. and Manually aiming your gun completely will give you +40% damage, but its up to your own instincts to react to targets approaching you.All the classes provide very good variety, if you got bored in one class you will find completely diffirent playstyle from another class. I love the RPG system. There are weapons & class specific skills to unlock for the first 50hours of the game (and its still a very, very long way to maximum rank). Playing a certain class gives statistical bonus to that class via Specialization rank. There is three diffirent maps you can play, and every game you can choose from 7 diffirent game modes ( popular are "Fast Mode" and "Bunker Mode"). I would give 2 recommendations to this game if I could.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Type of Game:Third Person Tactical Real-Time ShooterVersion Played:Early Access PC version through SteamSimilar Games:Warcraft 3: Night of the Dead mod, XCOM, and to a lesser degree Left 4 DeadThe Good:One of few games that offers 8 player coop over a non-local environment!Multiple classes to choose from, with unique abilities and loadouts that run the whole gamut of shooter/MOBA tacticsAssault, Heavy Support, Recon, Marksman, Demolition, Terminator, Hellfire, and MedicRandomly generated map content helps make every gaming session different and unpredictableRandomized missions also offer different objectives and locations that add to the replayability Also adding to the longevity of the game are the handful of different gametypes that place different changes to the setting and difficulty levelsA wide variety of weapons, which feature numerous stats that determined their purpose in varying combat scenariosThe music and sound effects are well done and aptly convey a sense of dread and suspenseThe story line and lore is complex and deep, which can assist with the player’s ability to immerse themselves in the gameThe game rewards great teamwork which is important to have in a tactical shooterVery few bugs and glitches for an early access title, especially considering the massive amount of content offeredThe plethora of achievements and rank unlocks help encourage game progressionThe Bad:Overall presentation is not very polished and doesn’t help market the immensely deep game underneath. A serious example of making sure not to judge a book (game) by its cover (presentation)The voice over during the beginning cutscene is atrocious and immediately puts the players expectations lowThe complex user interface and menus are also off putting and require putting time into the tutorial to fully understandWhile the tactics keep the gameplay varied, the actual gunplay can get repetitive though this can be said of most shootersThat said, if you aren’t a fan of shooters this won’t change your mind or opinionCan you play it while the children are awake?There is quite a lot of gun and other weapon-based violence. There, at least in my time with the game, is no profanity. I’d say it would be fine for children 8+, but that of course can vary depending on the child.Did I make time to complete it?This is primarily a multiplayer game, so completing it is not an option. I did, however, put numerous hours into it.Redlight or Greenlight?This game is currently at a greenlight.The content that is currently offered is well worth the asking price of $19.99. In fact, the amount of content is beyond most shooters that currently available as completed titles. I will say that I was interested in this game due to the RPG and progression elements, but I am typically not a fan of shooters. The last statement of the cons rings true for me as this game did not change my poor opinion of shooters. If you are a fan of the genre, however, you will find PLENTY to enjoy in The Red Solstice.A Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buyhttp://www.gamersglance.com

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015



YouTube™ Video: The Red Solstice Review 

			Views: 6,406		

			Cosmic reviews The Red Solstice an indie 8 man co-op tactical shooter developed by Ironward and published by Nikdu Games. This game was provided free of charge for the purpose of critique.		

Inspired by Warcraft 3 mods like Night of the Dead. The Red Solstice is a well-made 8 man co-op isometric tactical shooter that caters to fans of multiplayer games. The mechanics are solid, promote team work and the game can be very fun and frustrating in equal measure. It has a few bugs and quirks here and there and it’s not particular pleasant to look at but it retains a multiplayer experience that is difficult to find, It's worth a look.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Don't give a frak about MP and get pretty irritated with games who diss the SP part in favor of making things rediculous in SP. In the age of 5000 MP only games  where they mostly all fail eventually due to ignoring their SP to ive the game reason to at least be purchased long after the MP is dead. This is one that at least makes sure there's some SP there for those who do not care to deal with MP ommunties which usually = headache and idiocy..lmao First off, the game is based on a WC3 custom map called Night of the Dead. You are space marines prancing around a Mars colony full of zombies. You select a suit (read: class), a primary weapon, a secondary weapon, 4 suit components (read: skill...not trees. Paths, maybe? 5 sequential, mostly passive abilities), up to 3 powerups (which add some bonuses at the cost of other penalties), and you go off to try and survive a ~1 hour long match. You find items and accomplish objectives which will strengthen your team, while endless waves of zombies try to murder you to death. The customization isn't that deep, but you'll find plenty to tinker with if you're the fiddy sort. I enjoy it greatly. Worth the time and Dev support , even for just SP.

Early Access Review
								Genre - Co-op Squad based survivalOn paper this game sounds great to me. You are part of a squad of marines have to complete missions and protect each other from alien hordes. There are different classes with their own perks and unlocks as you play through the game. However, it doesn't quite work at the moment. The objectives are not clear and a lot of players tend to play bunker, which seems to involve staying in one place and killing endless swarms of aliens. When you do get into fighting the inventory is difficult to navigate and it is not clear what the stuff does. The shooting seems to just involve selecting auto aim and reloading when needed. Really wish I had invested in another early access game as think there is too much that needs changing here to make this game enjoyable, although I could be wrong...please prove me wrong developers!

content:
Posted: February 5
												My review is different from many of the other recent reviews.  I don't mind the single-player campaign.  It gets tough but I enjoy micro-managing the 4 units and upgrading each one.  You go into tactical mode and move each one, use their abilities etc.  I have no crashes on my Nvidia 780 with latest drivers.As for multiplayer, I've only tried a few times to get into games because I want to finish the campaign first.  I'm about half way through campaign with 8.5 hours played.  When I did join multiplayer, there were 2 games going and I had no issue getting into them.  From what I see, there is a diehard core group of players from Europe and US that play.  I can't really speak to much more of it than that.There is a tutorial level, and once you 'unlock' tactical mode, you realize that you can control each trooper and really set up some tactical advantages.  There's lots of places to look for crates/loot to help with your mission.  I usually have tons left over.  The spawns aren't endless, but watch your ammo.  There are devices that seal up some of the 'creature' holes so you can start taking back some of the maps and assist your missions.It's a game like Alien Swarm, if you could slow down alien swarm and micro manage each trooper.  Also kind of like Breach and Clear but with a lot more granularity.It's $8 on sale right now, which I feel is a REALLY good price.  At $20, I'd say try it, get through the first mission where you learn everything, and wait for the tactical mode lesson because that's the real mechanic to this game for singleplayer.  If you get through it, you should still be under your 2 hours, refund it.  It is still under active development, the devs just released a new game mode last week (2/1/17).

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Writing this review, I'll assume noone has played, "Night of the Dead", the Warcraft III mod this game was based on. The game in general plays like your average isometric shooter, with a bit of Dota thrown in. You start by choosing one of eight customizable classes, and then their loadout, including their primary and secondary weapon, the ammunition type they fire, up to four active/passive abilities, and 3 perks. As you rank up, the amount of each of these interchangable things you can use increases. Once your set, you can join a match with your customized soldier, and drop with up to 8 squad mates. The combat is fairly  simple. You move with right mouse click, and select targets and fire with the left. You can also allow your soldier to snap shot at targets automatically(aimbot) at the expense of accuracy. Your weapons use ammunition quickly, and unless you manage it carefully, you'll find yourself unarmed halfway through a match. Due to this, you have to scourage the environment for supplies, which you'll often find inside buildings, or on corpses. Once you find something, you can equip it into one of 6 item slots. The things you can find vary wildly, but they generally consist of explosives, medical supplies, ammunition, passive weapon upgrades, barricades, etc. Throughout this whole ordeal, you and your entire squad are trying to survive waves upon waves of hideous creatures trying to eat you, all the while trying to complete randomized objectives. At first glance this may seem fairly tame, but the enemy types vary wildly, from zombies, to giant bat demons, and they come from the darkness as the maps take place at night. To make matters worse, most often apply negative status effects to your soldiers. From bleeding wounds, bone fractures, and crippling toxins, you'll soon find yourself ravaged and left to die if you're not careful about patching yourself up and staying togethor with your teamates. As for game modes, the title currently has a tutorial, and online play with up to 8 player coop.The game is brutally difficult, even on the easier difficulties, but if you give it a shot, you'll find its highly addicting.

								This game is still in EARLY ACCESS but it's already awesome! If you're familiar with a little Blizzard mod called 'Night of the Dead' then you're instantly know this games style and genre.


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'The Red Solstice' PLUS 3 copies to giveaway! (ENDED) 

			Views: 97		

			I just found a BONUS copy of this game in my Steam Inventory. It's a gift copy with bonus copy of the game. So I'm going to pick another winner from the original comments below!		

Basically it's a rock-hard 8 player co-op survival game set in the distant future. It's not a game for the faint-hearted as you will die a lot. I've never played NoTD so this was all new to me. It felt like an isometric Killing Floor, and we all know how awesome Killing Floor is! number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a tactical survival game where your (up to) 8 person team must complete missions while surviving waves of zombie like creatures. Also, there is permanent death with only a few chances at revival. If your team survives until the end, then a match can last about 60-70ish minutes, but there is an option to call an early EVAC (if it is not lost or destroyed). There are multiple classes to choose from and each have their own set of abilities. Each class is fun to use, provides something different that is useful to the team, and there are limits on how many of the same type can be in a group, so I would say it's rather balanced in that regard. Also, playing as the medic (healer) is enjoyable, since they are constantly active and are seldom blamed for deaths. In game the abilities can be upgraded and downgraded, so that you can switch between for the task at hand.The current game is fun and replayable with the developers working to add more features for the final release. By the mid to end point in a game teamwork becomes key and each person gets to add to the effort whatever their class does.Now I will list some of the cons. Note that I am reviewing this game in it's beta state. - A lot of info about items and features in the game is not stated. This con is the first con because updating text is an easy fix and they have not. - There are some random crashes. Usually only a small amount of games crash so it is still quite playable, but after a patch it sometimes crashes much more often. - The community overall is fun to play with, but there is a bit of an issue with some people being jerks, such as telling you to pick this class with these skills and do exactly what they tell you to do the entire game or you're a ****ing noob. - At current there not as many players, but I think that stems from the two issues stated above (lack of needed info and people being jerks). This results in a longer time in queue, but not too bad.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This is a great game for its price. This is essenentially a squad based RTS game where you follow the story of Tyler  Hunt and some other marines to discover what happened to a colony on Mars. The story itself isn't what drew me in to really like this game though. I haven't even finished the story yet because I have been having such a good time just playing the multiplayer with the stellar community.Now I'v played the multiplayer for about 50 hours at this point and that is primarily playing as only one of seven classes available. In multiplayer you and 7 other members of your team work to complete missions and fight off hordes of monsters as you travel across a large map discovering what happened to Tyler Hunt and finding valuable loot to make you or your team stronger. Each multiplayer mission lasts about 40-50 minutes assuming your squad doesn't all die earlier in the mission. I highly recommend this game if you are looking for a co-op squad based RTS experience because the multiplayer is where this game really shines.

number of helpful: 19 of 38 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review (Subject to change) *videos coming up tomrrow*The game is a 8 player coop mission/objective rts style shooter with marines shooting down enemies that are infected with a virus, The gameplay is very similar to past mods from warcraft/starcraft called night of the dead except it is a very well done and solid carbon copy with a few bugs here and there that will need polishing up of course.This game is fun with 8 friends if you have them but is challenging and still as much fun with 8 random competent people. Communication is the key to survival in this game using skype or teamspeak whatever you can, or if you have a leader that actually can lead the entire group by giving directions and having the team listen. Hopefully a public voice chat of some kind is included in the future. The game offers at the moment one map with 2 different mode, the story mode with objectives and missions which are all randomized content where you'll want to complete as much as possible surviving on just one life  before you the timer which is about an hour hits 0 and your group gets overrun, also included is bunker mode where you'll defend a beacon and if it gets destroyed its game over however you can respawn every 30 seconds. The game also has 8 classes at the moment with a leveling system to unlock each one. Also each class has different abilities, skills, and weapons that you will want to use to your advantage. (as a group we've yet to beat the game yet lol but we are working on it)When starting up, players are introduced with a prologue  tutorial that teaches the player to the nice and clean interface along with how to use your abilities, levleing up, and your bread and butter skills which is flare, running, and autoaim. Very easy to learn if you have any hands on Rts at all.There are plenty of destructable objects in the environments with plenty of stuff to loot, generators to turn on and enemies to gun down. The game also has friendly fire with certain skills and explosives  so be careful where you call those napalm strikes or blowing up certain things because you might accidently shoot your teamate down. You'll be required to work together with those skills and passives to work on turning on radar, disabling enemy artillery from insurgents, or killing boss infecteds while conserving ammo by looting and exploring  and doing your best to use all items to your advantage from mines to rockets, to even turrets you can turn on or placeOther than that the bugs we discovered so far are not game breaking and the game plays pretty fun and solid for the time being. I found the game very exciting with a group of friends over teamspeak where we were trying to learn it and died to such dumb little things but this game is hard, REAL HARD even with the difficulty at easy so prepare yourself! We picked up plenty of pugs and had fun+ Massive hands on by the dev, Great interaction between dev and community+ This game isn't easy, I LOVE IT, prepare to get owned.+ Decent voice acting to give you the immersion and story of whats going on.+ Nicely done tutorial to introduce new players+ The gameplay is very fun especially when you have the right group+ A decent array of weapons and skills during set up phase (Need some polishing)+ Graphics is quite decent+  sound and music when you do hear it, gets you pumped for some of the action at the right time.+ A decent array of abilities for the classes that you can put points in during battle or reinvest.- Friendly Fire can be a dangerous thing, especially if someone goes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and wants to wipe the entire group out lol. A rep system would be nice.- Not really game breaking bugs but just wanted to put it here they exist so game needs a bit polish- Needs some polishing on class skills and balance.- A nice tune during the game so that it isnt completely silent the entire game, not too loud though lol- More maps!, Other planets, underground facilities and open areas. Can't wait to see what you guys come up with- Public mic communication would be nice!- Some type of drop in the game system so others can join while game is in session perhaps?*Gameplay Videos - working on it**Video review - Reserved till full game is released

Early Access Review
								If you've played NOTD or SWAT for Warcraft 3, you should find yourself at home with this difficult yet rewarding team survival title.If you haven't, you're going to die. Alot. And that's okay, the game is very much about sticking together, learning together and more often than not, dying together. This is a coop experience through and through.The bugs aren't gamebreaking and the devs keep the community relatively up to date on patches and upcoming changes. The controls, while complicated at first, become quite intuitive. You'll see what I mean when you've got a swarm of baddies on your squad's♥♥♥♥♥and your only recourse is a well placed satchel. When there's nothing left behind you except a pile of burning, dismembered alien corpses, you'll know that that sticking, learning and dying together paid off. And your squadmates will remember you for it.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												Very fun game alot of replayability for the price.  The game has a top down perspective with a rotatable camera, and is played via hot keys and issuing move and shoot commands via the mouse.  It plays akin to some custom games from war 3, and is reminiscent in how it feels playing to some of the old action games of the past like gauntlet and the like.  This game is hyper focused on team work, while certain classes and loadouts can get by soloing for a bit, everyone ends up having to group for surival.  Managing your ammo, explosives, CDs, and working as a team are the keys to this game.  Failing at any of those means death.  Game truly shines in multiplayer but the singleplayer isn't bad and helps you get used to the game via its tactical mode that lets your slow everything down.  Multiplayer of course doesn't use that though.  There are of course some negatives, the voice acting work in this game is really really bad, thankfully there isn't much of it.  There are also some poor ability descriptions leading to easy misunderstanding of how some things function.  There are also a few bugs (currently) that while not game breaking can be a slight annoyance.Still though I would reccomend picking this game up, its not an expensive game, and its certainly worth the cost for the hours you will get out of it.
